analyzed: sa tu vinihita grīvā kāṇḍaḥ kaṭāha puṭa antare svapiti bhagavān kūrmaḥ nidrā bhara alasa locanaḥ
translated: But the Lord Kūrma sleeps with his neck and shoulders inside the shell, his eyes languid with sleep.

original: bhaktiprahvavilokanapraṇayinī nīlotpalaspardhinī dhyānālambanatāṃ samādhiniratair nīte hitaprāptaye /
analyzed: bhakti prahva vilokana praṇayinī nīlotpala spardhinī dhyāna ālambana tām samādhi nirataiḥ nīte hita prāptaye
translated: His eyes, which are affectionate towards the sight of those humble with devotion, rivaling the blue lotus, are brought to the object of meditation by those devoted to meditation for the attainment of good.

original: lāvaṇyasya mahānidhī rasikatāṃ lakṣmīdṛśos tanvatī yuṣmākaṃ kurutāṃ bhavārtiśamanaṃ netre tanur vā hareḥ // / //
analyzed: lāvaṇyasya mahā nidhiḥ rasika tām lakṣmī dṛśoḥ tanvatī yuṣmākam kurutām bhava ārti śamanam netre tanuḥ vā hareḥ  /
translated: May the eyes or the body of Hari, which are a great treasure of beauty and make the eyes of Lakshmi full of rasa, bring about the destruction of the suffering of worldly existence for you all.

original: pucchodastavisāriṇo jalanidheḥ svargaṅgayā saṃgama śraddhāhūtakhalatpurātanamunir mīno hariḥ pātu vaḥ /
analyzed: puccha udasta visāriṇaḥ jalanidheḥ svargaṅgayā saṃgama śraddhā āhūta khalat purātana muniḥ mīnaḥ hariḥ pātu vaḥ
translated: May Lord Hari, the fish, protect you all, who, when the waters of the ocean spread to the tail, united with the heavenly Ganges, and the ancient sages, called by faith, were agitated,

original: yasminn uddharati śrutīḥ pṛthutarād oṃkārasāradhvaner madhyesindhu viyanmayo jalamayaḥ stambhas tv abhūd ambare // / //
analyzed: yasmin uddharati śrutīḥ pṛthutarāt oṃkāra sāra dhvaneḥ madhyesindhu viyat mayaḥ jala mayaḥ stambhaḥ tu abhūt ambare  /
translated: in the midst of which, the water-born pillar, full of space, became in the sky, from the loud sound of the essence of the syllable Om, which lifts up the Vedas from the vast expanse.

original: varjalamayaḥ/lem
analyzed: var jalam ayaḥ lem
translated: water-born.

original: emend/ /Ingalls /
analyzed: emend ingalls
translated: emendings.

original: jalamaya /edKG
analyzed: jala mayaḥ e t kg
translated: water-born.

original: jṛmbhāvijṛmbhitadṛśaḥ prathamaprabuddha lakṣmīkarāmburuhalālanalālasasya /
analyzed: jṛmbhā vijṛmbhita dṛśaḥ prathama prabuddha lakṣmī kara amburuha lālana lālasasya
translated: Of the one whose eyes are wide open with yawning, who is the first to awaken, and who is eager for the lotus hand of Lakshmi,

original: gātrāpavṛttibharakharvitaśeṣam avyād avyāhataṃ murajitaḥ kṛtakaprasuptam // / //
analyzed: gātra apavṛtti bhara kharvita śeṣam avyāt avyāhatam murajitaḥ kṛtaka prasuptam
translated: May the remaining body, heavy with the burden of movement, of the conqueror of Mura, who feigns sleep, be unharmed.

original: mayānviṣṭo dhūrtaḥ sa sakhi nikhilām eva rajanīm iha syād atra syād iti nipuṇam anyām abhisṛtaḥ /
analyzed: mayā anviṣṭaḥ dhūrtaḥ sa sakhi nikhilām eva rajanīm iha syāt atra syāt iti nipuṇam anyām abhisṛtaḥ
translated: O friend, that rogue whom I searched for all night, thinking he might be here or there, has cleverly gone elsewhere.

original: na dṛṣṭo bhāṇḍīre taṭabhuvi na govardhanagirer na kālindyāḥ kūle na ca niculakuñje muraripuḥ // / //
analyzed: na dṛṣṭaḥ bhāṇḍīre taṭa bhuvi na govardhana gireḥ na kālindyāḥ kūle na ca nicula kuñje muraripuḥ
translated: The enemy of Mura is not seen on the bank of the Bhaṇḍīra, nor on the Govardhana mountain, nor on the bank of the Kālindī, nor in the nicula grove.

original: śyāmoccandrā svapiṣi na śiśo naiti mām amba nidrā nidrāhetoḥ śṛṇu suta kathāṃ kām apūrvāṃ kuruṣva /
analyzed: śyāma uccandrā svapiṣi na śiśo nā eti mām amba nidrā nidrā hetoḥ śṛṇu suta kathām kām apūrvām kuruṣva
translated: O mother, the dark-hued moon is sleeping, but not me. Sleep does not come to me. For the sake of sleep, O son, listen to an unprecedented story, tell it.

original: rāmo nāma kṣitipatir abhūn mānanīyo raghūṇām ity uktasya smitam avatu vo devakīnandanasya // / //
analyzed: rāmaḥ nāma kṣitipatiḥ abhūt mānanīyaḥ raghūṇām iti uktasya smitam avatu vaḥ devakīnandanasya  /
translated: There was a king named Rama, revered by the Raghus. May the smile of the son of Devaki, when this was said to him, protect you all.

original: kharvagranthivimuktasandhivikasadvakṣaḥsphuratkaustubhaṃ niryannābhisarojakuḍmalakuṭīgambhīrasāmadhvani /
analyzed: kharva granthi vimukta sandhi vikasat vakṣaḥ sphurat kaustubham niryat nābhi saroja kuḍmala kuṭī gambhīra sāma dhvani
translated: With the Kaustubha gem shining on his chest, the joints of which are expanded from the knots of the dwarf form, and with the deep sound of the Sama Veda coming from the hut of the lotus bud in his navel,

original: pātrāvāptisamutsukena balinā sānandam ālokitaṃ pāyād vaḥ kramavardhamānamahimāścaryaṃ murārer vapuḥ // / //
analyzed: pātra avāpti samutsukena balinā sa ānandam ālokitam pāyāt vaḥ krama vardhamāna mahima āścaryam murāreḥ vapuḥ  /
translated: May the form of Murari, whose greatness increases step by step, be the protection of you all, which was joyfully looked at by Bali, eager to obtain a vessel,

original: uttiṣṭhantyā ratānte bharam uragapatau pāṇinaikena kṛtvā dhṛtvā cānyena vāso vigalitakabarībhāram aṃse vahantyāḥ /
analyzed: uttiṣṭhantyāḥ rata ante bharam uraga patau pāṇinā ekena kṛtvā dhṛtvā ca anyena vāsaḥ vigalita kabarī bhāram aṃse vahantyāḥ
translated: As she rises from lovemaking, holding up with one hand the weight of the lord of serpents, and with the other hand holding her garment, bearing the burden of her loosened braid on her shoulder,

original: bhūyas tatkālakāntidviguṇitasurataprītinā śauriṇā vaḥ śayyām ālambya nītaṃ vapur alasalasadbāhu lakṣmyāḥ punātu // / //
analyzed: bhūyas tad kāla kānti dvi guṇita surata prītinā śauriṇā vaḥ śayyām ālambya nītam vapuḥ alasa lasat bāhu lakṣmyāḥ punātu  /
translated: May Lakshmi's body, which was taken by Shouri, whose love for lovemaking was doubled by the beauty of that moment, leaning on the bed, with her arms languid, purify you all.

original: NB Ingalls tentatively suggests āliṅgya for ālambya in d /
analyzed: nb ingalls tentatively suggests āliṅgya for ālamb in
translated: N.B. Ingalls tentatively suggests embracing for leaning on in d.

original: varmaṃse/lem
analyzed: varmaṃselem
translated: In the flesh.

original: conj/ /Ingalls / maṃśaṃ /edKG
analyzed: c un in gal maṃśam e k g
translated: Conjunction.

original: sampūrṇaḥ punar abhyudeti kiraṇair indus tato dantinaḥ kumbhadvandvam idaṃ punaḥ surataror agrollasanmañjarī /
analyzed: sampūrṇaḥ punar abhyudeti kiraṇaiḥ induḥ tatas dantinaḥ kumbha dvandvam idam punar surataroḥ agra ullasat mañjarī
translated: The moon rises again in full with its rays, then this pair of tusks of the elephant, and again the bud that shines at the top of the pleasure garden tree.

original: itthaṃ yadvadanastanadvayavaladromāvalīṣu bhramaḥ kṣīrābdher mathane 'bhavad diviṣadāṃ lakṣmīr asāv astu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: ittham yat vadana stana dvaya valat roma āvalīṣu bhramaḥ kṣīrābdheḥ mathane bhavat diviṣadām lakṣmīḥ asau astu vaḥ  /
translated: Thus, may that Lakshmi of the gods, who was confused in the churning of the milk ocean among the lip, breasts, and row of hair, be for your welfare.

original: bhabhabhramati kiṃ mahī lalalalambate candramāḥ kṛkṛṣṇa vavada drutaṃ hahahasanti kiṃ vṛṣṇayaḥ /
analyzed: bhabhabhramati kim mahī lalalalambate candramāḥ kṛkṛṣṇa vavada drutam haha hasanti kim vṛṣṇayaḥ
translated: The earth is spinning, the moon is hanging down, O Krishna, speak quickly, are the Vrishnis laughing?

original: śiśīdhu mumumuñca me vavavavaktram ityādikaṃ madaskhalitam ālapan haladharaḥ śriyaṃ vaḥ kriyāt // / //
analyzed: śiśīdhu mumumuñca me iti ādikam mada skhalitam ālapan haladharaḥ śriyam vaḥ kriyāt  /
translated: Release the wine to my mouth, speaking with such stammering intoxication, may the plough-bearer bring you prosperity.

original: puruṣottamadevasya
analyzed: puruṣottama devasya
translated: Of Purushottamadeva

original: kiṃ kiṃ siṃhas tataḥ kiṃ narasadṛśavapur deva citraṃ gṛhīto naivaṃ tat ko 'tra jīva drutam upanaya taṃ nanv ayaṃ prāpta eva /
analyzed: kim kim siṃhaḥ tatas kim nara sadṛśa vapuḥ deva citram gṛhītaḥ nā evam tat kaḥ tra jīva drutam upanaya tam nanu ayam prāptaḥ eva
translated: What? What? The lion? Then, how is it that a body like a man is taken, O god, it is strange. Thus, who is alive here? Quickly bring him, indeed he has arrived.

original: cāpaṃ cāpaṃ na khaḍgaṃ tvaritataram aho karkaśatvaṃ nakhānām itthaṃ daityādhirājaṃ nijanakhakuliśair jaghnivān yaḥ sa vo 'vyāt // /🔽devas tvām ekajaṅghāvalayitalaguḍo mūrdhni vinyastabāhur gāyan goyuddhagītīr uparacitaśiraḥśekharaḥ pragraheṇa /
analyzed: cāpam cāpam na khaḍgam tvaritataram aho karkaśa tvam nakhānām ittham daitya adhirājam nija nakha kuliśaiḥ jaghnivān yaḥ sa vaḥ vyāt  devaḥ tvām eka jaṅghā valayita laguḍaḥ mūrdhni vinyasta bāhuḥ gāyan go yuddha gītīḥ uparacita śiraḥ śekharaḥ pragraheṇa
translated: May he, who thus struck the king of demons with his own fingernails, which were more quickly drawn than a bow or sword, protect you all.🔽The god, with his arm placed on his head, his stick twined around his single leg, singing the songs of the bullfight, with his crest made of the head,

original: darpasphūrjanmahokṣadvayasamarasarasābaddhadīrghānurāgaḥ krīḍāgopālamūrtir muraripur avatād āttagorakṣalīlaḥ // / //
analyzed: darpa sphūrjat mahā ukṣa dvaya sama rasa rasa ābaddha dīrgha anurāgaḥ krīḍā gopāla mūrtiḥ muraripuḥ avatāt ātta gorakṣa līlaḥ  /
translated: with his long affection bound by the passion of the battle of the two proud and thundering bulls, may the enemy of Mura, in the form of a playful cowherd, protect you, taking up the play of protecting the cows.

original: śrīsonnokasya
analyzed: śrī sonnokasya
translated: Of Sri Sonnok

original: jayanti nirdāritadaityavakṣaso nṛsiṃharūpasya harer nakhāṅkurāḥ /
analyzed: jayanti nirdārita daitya vakṣasaḥ nṛsiṃha rūpasya hareḥ nakha aṅkurāḥ
translated: The claws of Hari in the form of Narasimha, who tore open the chest of the demon, are victorious.

original: vicintya yeṣāṃ caritaṃ surārayaḥ priyānakhebhyo 'pi rateṣu bibhyati // / //
analyzed: vicintya yeṣām caritam surārayaḥ rateṣu bibhyati  /
translated: Thinking of whose deeds, the enemies of the gods are afraid of their beloved claws even in love-making.

original: ete lakṣmaṇa jānakīvirahiṇaṃ māṃ khedayanty ambudā marmāṇīva ca ghaṭṭayanty alam amī krūrāḥ kadambānilāḥ /
analyzed: ete lakṣmaṇa jānakī virahiṇam mām khedayanti ambudāḥ marmāṇi iva ca ghaṭṭayanti alam amī krūrāḥ kadamba anilāḥ
translated: These clouds, O Lakshmana, torment me who am separated from Janaki, and these cruel kadamba breezes rub my heart as if with salt.

original: itthaṃ vyāhṛtapūrvajanmaviraho yo rādhayā vīkṣitaḥ serṣyaṃ śaṅkitayā sa vaḥ sukhayatu svaprāyamāno hariḥ // / //
analyzed: ittham vyāhṛta pūrva janma virahaḥ yaḥ rādhayā vīkṣitaḥ sa īrṣyam śaṅkitayā sa vaḥ sukhayatu sva prāyamānaḥ hariḥ
translated: May Hari, who was thus seen by Rādhikā, with her former birth revealed, with jealousy, with suspicion, and who is now absorbed in his own thoughts, bring you happiness.

original: mithyākāṇḍūtisācīkṛtagalasaraṇir yeṣu jāto garutmān ye nidrāṃ nāṭayadbhiḥ śayanaphaṇiphaṇair lakṣitā na śrutāś ca /
analyzed: mithyā kāṇḍūti sācīkṛta gala saraṇiḥ yeṣu jātaḥ garutmān ye nidrām nāṭayadbhiḥ śayana phaṇi phaṇaiḥ lakṣitāḥ na śrutāḥ ca
translated: May the amorous sports of Mādhava, which were not seen by Garuḍa, whose neck was turned aside by the false itching sensation, which were not heard by the hoods of the sleeping serpent-couch, which were marked by the hoods of the serpent-couch pretending to sleep,

original: ye ca dhyānānubandhacchalamukuladṛśā vedhasā naiva dṛṣṭās te lakṣmīṃ narmayanto nidhuvanavidhayaḥ pāntu vo mādhavasya // /
analyzed: ye ca dhyāna anubandha chala mukula dṛśā vedhasā nā eva dṛṣṭāḥ te lakṣmīm narmayantaḥ nidhuvana vidhayaḥ pāntu vaḥ mādhavasya  /
translated: and which were not seen even by Brahmā with his eyes closed in the guise of deep meditation, protect you all, making Lakṣmī laugh.

original: rājaśekharasya🔽pratyagronmeṣajihmā kṣaṇam anabhimukhī ratnadīpaprabhāṇām ātmavyāpāragurvī janitajalalavā jṛmbhitaiḥ sāṅgabhaṅgaiḥ /
analyzed: rājaśekharasya  pratyagra unmeṣa jihmā kṣaṇam an abhimukhī ratna dīpa prabhāṇām ātma vyāpāra gurvī janita jala lavā jṛmbhitaiḥ sa aṅga bhaṅgaiḥ
translated: Of Rājaśekhara🔽The body of the elephant, slightly crooked for a moment due to the fresh opening of the eyes, not facing the light of the jewel lamps, heavy with its own movements, with the drops of water produced by yawning along with the bending of the limbs,

original: nāgāṅgaṃ moktum icchoḥ śayanam uruphaṇācakravālopadhānaṃ nidrācchedābhitāmrā ciram avatu harer dṛṣṭir ākekarā vaḥ // / //
analyzed: nāga aṅgam moktum icchoḥ śayanam uru phaṇā cakravāla upadhānam nidrā cheda abhitāmrā ciram avatu hareḥ dṛṣṭiḥ ākekarā vaḥ  /
translated: may the single-pointed gaze of Hari, reddish due to the interruption of sleep, for a long time, protect you all, desiring to release the body of the elephant, with the pillow of the large hood-circle, from sleep.

original: viśākhadattasya
analyzed: viśākhadattasya
translated: Of Viśākhadatta

original: daṃṣṭrāpiṣṭeṣu sadyaḥ śikhariṣu na kṛtaḥ skandhakaṇḍūvinodaḥ sindhuṣv aṅgāvagāhaḥ khurakuharaviśattoyatuccheṣu nāptaḥ /
analyzed: daṃṣṭrā piṣṭeṣu sadyas śikhariṣu na kṛtaḥ skandha kaṇḍū vinodaḥ sindhuṣu aṅga avagāhaḥ khura kuhara viśat toya tuccheṣu na āptaḥ
translated: When the mountains were crushed by his tusks, he did not scratch his shoulders; when the rivers had little water left, flowing through the holes in his hooves, he did not plunge his body into them;

original: prāptāḥ pātālapaṅke na luṭhanaratayaḥ potramātropayukte yenoddhāre dharitryāḥ sa jayati vibhutāvighniteccho varāhaḥ // / //
analyzed: prāptāḥ pātāla paṅke na luṭhana ratayaḥ potra mātra upayukte yena uddhāre dharitryāḥ sa jayati vibhu tā vighni tā icchaḥ varāhaḥ  /
translated: when the earth was lifted up by him, he did not find pleasure in rolling in the mud of the nether regions, using only his snout. May that boar, whose desire to lift the earth was obstructed by his greatness, be victorious.

original: varāhamihirasya🔽pātu trīṇi jaganti pārśvakaṣaṇaprakṣuṇṇadigmaṇḍalo naikābdhistimitodaraḥ sa bhagavān krīḍājhaṣaḥ keśavaḥ /
analyzed: varāhamihirasya  pātu trīṇi jaganti pārśva kaṣaṇa prakṣuṇṇa diś maṇḍalaḥ na eka abdhi stimita udaraḥ sa bhagavān krīḍā jhaṣaḥ keśavaḥ
translated: Of Varāhamihira🔽May that Lord Kṛṣṇa, the playful dolphin, protect the three worlds, with his belly motionless like an ocean, his body scratched by rubbing against the sides of the world,

original: tvaṅganniṣṭhurapṛṣṭharomakhacitabrahmāṇḍabhāṇḍasthiter yasyotsphālakutūhalena katham apy aṅgeṣu jīrṇāyitam // / //
analyzed: tu aṅgat niṣṭhura pṛṣṭha roma khacita brahmāṇḍa bhāṇḍa sthiteḥ yasya utsphāla kutūhalena katham api aṅgeṣu
translated: whose curiosity to leap somehow became old in his limbs, while he was situated in the vessel of the universe, his back covered with stiff hair.

original: raghunandanasya
analyzed: raghunandanasya
translated: Of Raghunandana

original: ye saṃtāpitanābhipadmamadhavo ye snāpitoraḥsrajo ye tāpāt taralena talpaphaṇinā prītapratīpojjhitāḥ /
analyzed: ye saṃtāpita nābhi padma madhavaḥ ye snāpita uraḥsrajaḥ ye tāpāt taralena talpa phaṇinā prīta pratīpa ujjhitāḥ
translated: Those who have scorched the lotus of the navel, who have bathed the garland on the chest, who have been abandoned by the fickle serpent on the bed due to heat,

original: ye rādhāsmṛtisākṣiṇaḥ kamalayā sāsūyam ākīrṇitā gāḍhāntardavathoḥ prataptasaralāḥ śvāsā hareḥ pāntu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: ye rādhā smṛti sākṣiṇaḥ kamalayā sa asūyam ākīrṇitāḥ gāḍha antar davathoḥ pratapta saralāḥ śvāsāḥ hareḥ pāntu vaḥ  /
translated: May the sighs of Hari, which are filled with jealousy by the lotus-eyed Radha, which are deeply troubled within, and which are straightforward and heated, protect you all.

original: puṣpākasya🔽seyaṃ dyaus tad idaṃ śaśāṅkadinakṛccihnaṃ nabhaḥ sā kṣitis tat pātālatalaṃ ta eva girayas te 'mbhodhayas tā diśaḥ /
analyzed: puṣpākasya  sā iyam dyauḥ tat idam śaśāṅka dinakṛt cihnam nabhaḥ sā kṣitiḥ tat pātāla talam te eva girayaḥ te mbhodhayaḥ tāḥ diśaḥ
translated: Of Pushpaka🔽This is the sky, that is the sky marked by the moon and sun, that is the earth, that is the nether world, those are the mountains, those are the oceans, those are the directions.

original: itthaṃ nābhivinirgatena saśiraḥkampādbhutaṃ vedhasā yasyāntaś ca bahiś ca dṛṣṭam akhilaṃ trailokyam avyāt sa vaḥ // / //
analyzed: ittham nābhi vinirgatena sa śiraḥ kampa adbhutam vedhasā yasya antar ca bahis ca dṛṣṭam akhilam trailokyam avyāt sa vaḥ  /
translated: Thus, by the wonderful Brahmā, who emerged from the navel with a trembling head, having seen the entire three worlds inside and outside, may that protect you all.

original: yuktaṃ mānada mām ananyamanasaṃ vakṣaḥsthalasthāyinīṃ bhaktām apy avadhūya kartum adhunā kāntāsahasraṃ tava /
analyzed: yuktam mānada mām an anya manasam vakṣaḥ sthala sthāyinīm bhaktām api avadhūya kartum adhunā kāntā sahasram tava
translated: It is proper, O giver of honor, to abandon me, who am devoted and have no other mind, who dwell in your chest, and to make a thousand beloveds now.

original: ity uktvā phaṇabhṛtphaṇāmaṇigatāṃ svām eva mantvā tanuṃ nidrācchedakaraṃ harer avatu vo lakṣmyā vilakṣasmitam // / //
analyzed: iti uktvā phaṇabhṛt phaṇāmaṇi gatām svām eva mantvā tanum nidrā cheda karam hareḥ avatu vaḥ lakṣmyāḥ vilakṣa smitam
translated: Having said this, thinking of her own body, which is on the crest-jewel of the serpent, may Lakshmi's bashful smile, which interrupts Hari's sleep, protect you all.

original: bhāsasya
analyzed: bhāsasya
translated: Of Bhasa

original: agre gacchata dhenudagdhakalaśān ādāya gopyo gṛhaṃ dugdhe vaskayaṇīkule punar iyaṃ rādhā śanair yāsyati /
analyzed: agre gacchata dhenu dagdha kalaśān ādāya gopyaḥ gṛham dugdhe vaskayaṇī kule punar iyam rādhā śanais yāsyati
translated: The cowherdesses are going ahead, carrying pots burnt by the cow's milk, and this Radha will slowly go back to the cowherd village.

original: ity anyavyapadeśaguptahṛdayaḥ kurvan viviktaṃ vrajaṃ devaḥ kāraṇanandasūnur aśivaṃ kṛṣṇaḥ sa muṣṇātu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: iti anya vyapadeśa gupta hṛdayaḥ kurvan viviktam vrajam devaḥ kāraṇa nanda sūnuḥ aśivam kṛṣṇaḥ sa muṣṇātu vaḥ  /
translated: Thus, may Krishna, the god, the son of Nanda, the cause of joy, with a heart hidden by the designation of another, and making the cowherds' colony secluded, may that Krishna destroy your inauspiciousness.

original: satrāsārti yaśodayā priyaguṇaprītekṣaṇaṃ rādhayā lagnair ballavasūnubhiḥ sarabhasaṃ sambhāvitātmorjitaiḥ /
analyzed: sa trāsa ārti yaśodayā priya guṇa prīta īkṣaṇam rādhayā lagnaiḥ ballava sūnubhiḥ sarabhasam sambhāvita ātma ūrjitaiḥ
translated: Looked at with eyes delighted by the good qualities of Radha, who is distressed with fear, and with eyes full of love for her dear qualities,

original: bhītānanditavismitena viṣamaṃ nandena cālokitaḥ pāyād vaḥ karamūrdhasusthitamahāśailaḥ salīlo hariḥ // / //
analyzed: bhīta ānandita vismitena viṣamam nandena ca ālokitaḥ pāyāt vaḥ kara mūrdha susthita mahā śailaḥ sa līlaḥ hariḥ
translated: Looked at with eyes of joy, delight, and wonder by the fearful Nanda, may Hari, with his great mountain resting on the crown of his head, protect you with grace.

original: sonnokasyaitau🔽daṃṣṭrāsaṅkaṭavaktrakandaratarajjihvābhṛto havyabhug jvālābhāsurabhūrikeśarisaṭābhārasya daityadruhaḥ /
analyzed: sa unna ukasya etau  daṃṣṭrā saṅkaṭa vaktra kandara tarat jihvā bhṛtaḥ havyabhuj jvālā bhāsura bhūri keśari saṭā bhārasya daitya druhaḥ
translated: These two are of Soṇṇoka.🔽The fire god, with a tongue flickering in the deep cave of his mouth with sharp fangs, with a mass of mane shining with flames, the enemy of the demons,

original: vyāvalgadbalavaddhiraṇyakaśipukroḍasthalīpāṭana spaṣṭaprasphuṭadasthipañjararavakrūrā nakhāḥ pāntu vaḥ // / //
analyzed: vyāvalgat balavat hiraṇyakaśipu kroḍa sthalīpāṭana spaṣṭa prasphuṭat asthipañjara rava krūrāḥ nakhāḥ pāntu vaḥ  /
translated: May his fierce claws, which make a loud sound when the skeleton is clearly split open, protect you, as he violently tears apart the chest of the powerful Hiranyakashipu.

original: vākpateḥ
analyzed: vākpateḥ
translated: Of Vakpati

original: lakṣmyāḥ keśaprasavarajasāṃ bindubhiḥ sāndrapātair abhyarṇaśrīr ghananidhuvanaklāntinidrāntareṣu /
analyzed: lakṣmyāḥ keśa prasava rajasām bindubhiḥ sāndra pātaiḥ abhyarṇa śrīḥ ghana nidhuvana klānti nidrā antareṣu
translated: In the intervals of sleep from exhaustion in intense lovemaking, with drops of the pollen from Lakshmi's hair falling thickly all around,

original: dordaṇḍo 'sau jayati jayinaḥ śārṅgiṇo mandarādri grāvaśreṇīnikaṣamasṛṇakṣuṇṇakeyūrapatraḥ // / //
analyzed: sau jayati jayinaḥ śārṅgiṇaḥ mandara adri grāva śreṇī nikaṣa masṛṇa kṣuṇṇa keyūra patraḥ
translated: That arm of the victorious wielder of the Sharnga bow, which is rubbed by the soft keyura-leaf while crushing the series of peaks of the Mandara mountain, is victorious.

original: NB Ingalls conjectures suvarṇaśrīḥ for abhyarṇaśrīḥ in b /
analyzed: nb ingalls conjectures suvarṇa śrīḥ for abhyarṇa śrīḥ in b
translated: N.B. Ingalls conjectures suvarnashri for abhyarnashri in B.

original: śrībhagīrathasya🔽nakhakrakacadāraṇasphuṭitadaityavakṣaḥsthala kṣaratkṣatajanirjharaprativibhāvitasvākṛteḥ /
analyzed: śrī bhagīrathasya  nakha krakaca dāraṇa sphuṭita daitya vakṣaḥ sthala kṣarat kṣataja nirjhara prativibhāvita su ākṛteḥ
translated: Of Shri Bhagiratha🔽The form of Hari, who is manifested by the waterfalls of blood flowing from the chests of demons split open by the sharp claws of his nails,

original: harer aparakeśarikṣubhitacetasaḥ pātu vaḥ saroṣalalitādharabhrukuṭibhaṅgabhīmaṃ mukham // / //
analyzed: hareḥ apara kesari kṣubhita cetasaḥ pātu vaḥ sa roṣa lalita adhara bhrukuṭi bhaṅga bhīmam mukham
translated: May the face of him, whose mind is agitated by the hair of the demon Keshi, protect you, with a frown on his beautiful angry lips, terrible with a frown.

original: vākpatirājasya
analyzed: vākpatirājasya
translated: Of Vakpatirāja

original: vatsa kṣmādharagahvareṣu vicaraṃś cārapracāre gavāṃ hiṃsrān vīkṣya puraḥ purāṇapuruṣaṃ nārāyaṇaṃ dhyāsyasi /
analyzed: vatsa kṣmādhara gahvareṣu vicaran cāra pracāre gavām hiṃsrān vīkṣya puras purāṇapuruṣam nārāyaṇam dhyāsyasi
translated: O child, wandering in the caves of the mountain, seeing the fierce ones in front of the cows, you will meditate on the ancient supreme being, Narayana.

original: ity uktasya yaśodayā muraripor avyāj jaganti sphurad bimboṣṭhadvayagāḍhapīḍanavaśād avyaktabhāvaṃ smitam // / //
analyzed: iti uktasya yaśodayā muraripoḥ avyāt jaganti sphurat bimba uṣṭha dvaya gāḍha pīḍana vaśāt avyakta bhāvam smitam
translated: Thus addressed by Yashoda, the enemy of Mura, the universe was pressed tightly between his two shining lips, and a smile appeared indistinctly.

original: devo harir jayati yajñavarāharūpaḥ sṛṣṭisthitipralayakāraṇam eka eva /
analyzed: devaḥ hariḥ jayati yajñavarāha rūpaḥ sṛṣṭi sthiti pralaya kāraṇam ekaḥ eva
translated: The god Hari, in the form of the sacrificial boar, is victorious, the sole cause of creation, sustenance, and dissolution.

original: yasyodarasthitajagattrayabījakośa nirgacchadaṅkuraśikheva vibhāti daṃṣṭrā // / //
analyzed: yasya udara sthita jagattraya bīja kośa nirgacchat aṅkura śikhā iva vibhāti daṃṣṭrā
translated: Whose tusk shines forth like the sprout of the seed-pod of the three worlds contained in his belly.

original: sonnokasya
analyzed: sa unnokasya
translated: Of Sonoka

original: bījaṃ brahmaiva devo madhu jalanidhayaḥ karṇikā svarṇaśailaḥ kandaṃ nāgādhirājo viyad ativipulaḥ patrakośāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: bījam brahmā eva devaḥ madhu jalanidhayaḥ karṇikā svarṇa śailaḥ kandam nāga adhirājaḥ viyat ati vipulaḥ patra kośa avakāśaḥ
translated: The seed is Brahman itself, the god, the honey is the oceans, the pericarp is the golden mountain, the bulb is the king of serpents, the space of the wide-open leaves is the sky,

original: dvīpāḥ patrāṇi meghā madhupakulam amūs tārakā garbhadhūlir yasyaitan nābhipadmaṃ bhuvanam iti sa vaḥ śarma devo dadātu // /
analyzed: dvīpāḥ patrāṇi meghāḥ madhupa kulam amūḥ tārakāḥ garbha dhūliḥ yasya etat nābhi padmam bhuvanam iti sa vaḥ śarma devaḥ dadātu  /
translated: The continents are the leaves, the clouds are the swarm of bees, the stars are the pollen dust of that lotus of his navel, which is the world. May that god grant you all welfare.

original: mālāyudhasya
analyzed: mālāyudhasya
translated: Of Mālaya-Yudha

original: kanakanikaṣasvacche rādhāpayodharamaṇḍale navajaladharaśyāmām ātmadyutiṃ pratibimbitām /
analyzed: kanaka nikaṣa su acche rādhā payodhara maṇḍale nava jaladhara śyāmām ātma dyutim pratibimbitām
translated: On the orb of Rādhā's breasts, clear as a gold standard, the dark radiance of her own body is reflected, like a fresh rain cloud,

original: asitasicayaprāntabhrāntyā muhur muhur utkṣipañ jayati janitavrīḍānamrapriyāhasino hariḥ // / //
analyzed: asita sicaya prānta bhrāntyā muhur muhur utkṣipam jayati janita vrīḍā ānamra priyā hasinaḥ hariḥ
translated: Again and again raising it, thinking it is the edge of a black garment, Hari triumphs, with his beloved laughing in embarrassment and bowing down in shame.

original: vaiddokasya
analyzed: vaiddokasya
translated: Of Vaiddhoka

original: Colo iti viṣṇuvrajyā//
analyzed: iti viṣṇuvrajyā
translated: The garland is thus the chapter on Vishnu.

original: tataḥ sūryavrajyā
analyzed: tatas sūryavrajyā
translated: Then the chapter on the Sun

original: yasyādho 'dhas tathopary upari niravadhi bhrāmyato viśvam aśvair āvṛttālātalīlāṃ racayati rayato maṇḍalaṃ tigmadhāmnaḥ /
analyzed: yasya adhas tathā upari upari niravadhi bhrāmyataḥ viśvam aśvaiḥ āvṛtta alāta līlām racayati rayataḥ maṇḍalam tigmadhāmnaḥ
translated: Below and above, endlessly whirling with the horses of the universe, the orb of the fierce-rayed one creates the play of a whirling firebrand,

original: so 'vyād uttaptakārtasvarasaralaśaraspardhibhir dhāmadaṇḍair uddaṇḍaiḥ prāpayan vaḥ pracuratamatamaḥstomam astaṃ samastam // /
analyzed: saḥ uttapta kārtasvara sarala śara spardhibhiḥ dhāma daṇḍaiḥ uddaṇḍaiḥ prāpayan vaḥ pracuratama tamaḥ stomam astam samastam  /
translated: May he, with his uplifted golden rods, rivaling the straight-growing reeds, dispel your entire mass of thick darkness, and lead you to the highest state.

original: rājaśekharasya🔽śukatuṇḍacchavi savituś caṇḍarucaḥ puṇḍarīkavanabandhoḥ /
analyzed: rājaśekharasya  śukatuṇḍa chavi savituḥ caṇḍa rucaḥ puṇḍarīkavana bandhoḥ
translated: Of Rājaśekhara🔽I pay homage to the orb of the sun, which is like the beak of a parrot, the fierce light of the sun, the friend of the lotus grove,

original: maṇḍalam uditaṃ vande kuṇḍalam ākhaṇḍalāśāyāḥ // / //
analyzed: maṇḍalam uditam vande kuṇḍalam ākhaṇḍala āśāyāḥ
translated: the earring of Indra, the lord of the quarters, which is rising,

original: vidyāyāḥ🔽tuṅgodayādribhujagendraphaṇopalāya vyomendranīlatarukāñcanapallavāya /
analyzed: vidyāyāḥ  tuṅga udaya adri bhujaga indra phaṇa upalāya vyoma indranīla taru kāñcana pallavāya
translated: of learning.🔽To the sun, which is like the jewels on the hoods of the great serpents in the eastern mountain, which has the golden sprouts of the sapphire trees in the sky,

original: saṃsārasāgarasamutkramayogisārtha prasthānapūrṇakalaśāya namaḥ savitre // / //
analyzed: saṃsāra sāgara samutkrama yogi sārtha prasthāna pūrṇa kalaśāya namaḥ savitre
translated: to the full water pot of the journey of the company of sages who have crossed the ocean of worldly existence, I offer salutations to the sun.

original: varāhamihirasya🔽saṃsaktaṃ siktamūlād abhinavabhuvanodyānakautūhalinyā yāminyā kanyayevāmṛtakarakalaśāvarjitenāmṛtena /
analyzed: varāhamihirasya  saṃsaktam sikta mūlāt abhinava bhuvana udyāna kautūhalinyā yāminyā kanyayā iva amṛta kara kalaśa āvarjitena amṛtena
translated: Of Varāhamihira🔽May the light of the sun, which is sprinkled with nectar brought in a golden pot by the daughter of the night, who is curious about the new garden of the world, as if it were sprinkled at the root,

original: arkālokaḥ kriyād vo mudam udayaśiraścakravālālavālād udyan bālapravālapratimarucir ahaḥpādapaprākpravālaḥ // / //
analyzed: arka ālokaḥ kriyāt vaḥ mudam udayaśiraḥ cakravāla ālavālāt udyan bāla pravāla pratima ruciḥ ahar pādapa prāc pravālaḥ  /
translated: may the eastern sprout of the tree of the day, which is rising from the basin of the eastern mountain, with a color like a young coral, bring you joy.

original: mayūrasya🔽Colo iti sūryavrajyā//
analyzed: mayūrasya  iti sūryavrajyā
translated: Of Mayūra🔽The chapter on the sun is concluded.

original: tato vasantavrajyā//
analyzed: tatas vasantavrajyā
translated: Then comes the chapter on spring.

original: āraktāṅkuradanturā kamalinī nāyāminī yāminī stokonmuktatuṣāram ambaramaṇer īṣatpragalbhaṃ mahaḥ /
analyzed: ārakta aṅkura danturā kamalinī nā āyāminī yāminī stoka unmukta tuṣāram ambaramaṇeḥ īṣat pragalbham mahaḥ
translated: The lotus pond is sparse with buds and shoots, the night is not long, the sky-jewel's light is slightly bold, freed from a little frost.

original: apy ete sahakārasaurabhamuco vācālitāḥ kokilair āyānti priyaviprayuktayuvatīmarmacchido vāsarāḥ // / //
analyzed: api ete sahakāra saurabha mucaḥ vā ācālitāḥ kokilaiḥ āyānti priya viprayukta yuvatī marma chidaḥ vāsarāḥ
translated: These days, exhaling the fragrance of mango blossoms, and coaxed by cuckoos, are coming, cutting to the quick the young women separated from their lovers.

original: saṃghaśriyaḥ
analyzed: saṃgha śriyaḥ
translated: [of Saṃghaśrī]

original: naivaike vayam eva kokilavadhūkaṇṭhoccaratpañcama sthānodbodhitapañcamārgaṇaguṇāsphālena romāñcitāḥ /
analyzed: na eva eke vayam eva kokila vadhū kaṇṭha uccarat pañcama sthāna udbodhita pañca mārgaṇa guṇa āsphālena romāñcitāḥ
translated: We are not alone in being thrilled by the sound of the fifth note, uttered from the throats of the female cuckoos, which awakens the qualities of the fifth path.

original: paśyaite taravo 'pi sundari jaratpatravyayānantarod bhinnapāṭalakoṭisampuṭadalaprādurbhavatkuḍmalāḥ // / //
analyzed: paśya ete taravaḥ sundari jarat patra vyaya anantara ud bhinna pāṭala koṭi sampuṭa dala prādurbhavat kuḍmalāḥ
translated: Look, O beautiful one, even these trees, after the fall of old leaves, are producing buds with the appearance of clusters of reddish sprouts.

original: vinayadevasya
analyzed: vinayadevasya
translated: [of Vinayadeva]

original: malayamahīdharapavanaḥ kalakaṇṭhakaladhvanir nikuñjalatāḥ /
translated: The wind from the Malaya mountain, the sweet sound of the cuckoo, and the vines in the groves,

original: utkalikā utkalikāś cetasi janayanti lokasya // / //
analyzed: utkalikāḥ utkalikāḥ cetasi janayanti lokasya  /
translated: produce a flurry of excitement in the minds of people.

original: kāntena prahito navaḥ priyasakhīvargeṇa baddhaspṛhaś cittenopahṛtaḥ smarāya na samutsraṣṭuṃ gataḥ pāṇinā /
analyzed: kāntena prahitaḥ navaḥ priya sakhī vargeṇa baddha spṛhaḥ cittena upahṛtaḥ smarāya na samutsraṣṭum gataḥ pāṇinā
translated: Sent by the lover, newly arrived, eagerly embraced by the group of dear friends, offered by the mind to the god of love, not released by the hand,

original: āmṛṣṭo muhur īkṣito muhur abhighrāto muhur loṭhitaḥ pratyaṅgaṃ ca muhuḥ kṛto mṛgadṛśā kiṃ kiṃ na cūtāṅkuraḥ // / //
analyzed: āmṛṣṭaḥ muhur īkṣitaḥ muhur abhighrātaḥ muhur loṭhitaḥ pratyaṅgam ca muhur kṛtaḥ mṛga dṛśā kim kim na cūta aṅkuraḥ  /
translated: The mango bud, repeatedly touched, looked at again and again, smelt over and over, rolled about, and repeatedly placed on different parts of the body by the doe-eyed one - what is it not capable of?

original: vākkuṭasya
analyzed: vākkuṭasya
translated: Of Vakkuta

original: dvis triḥ kokilayā rutaṃ tricaturaiś cūtāṅkurair udgataṃ koṣān bobhrati kiṃśukā madhukaraśreṇījuṣaḥ pañcaṣān /
analyzed: dvis tris kokilayā rutam tricaturaiḥ cūta aṅkuraiḥ udgatam koṣān bobhrati kiṃśukāḥ madhukara śreṇī juṣaḥ pañcaṣān
translated: The cuckoo has cooed twice or thrice, the mango buds have sprouted three or four times, the kinshuka trees are bursting forth from their sheaths, and the bees are enjoying the five or six [petals].

original: kvāpi kvāpi madākulākulatayā kāntāparādhagraha granthicchedasamudyataṃ ca hṛdayaṃ dolāyate subhruvām // / //
analyzed: kvāpi kvāpi mada ākula ākula tayā kānta aparādha graha granthi cheda samudyatam ca hṛdayam dolāyate subhruvām
translated: Here and there, the hearts of the beautiful-browed women, ready to cut the knot of the offense of their lovers due to their agitated state of intoxication, are wavering.

original: nīlasya
analyzed: nīlasya
translated: Of Nila

original: jambūnāṃ kusumodareṣv atirasād ābaddhapānotsavāḥ kīrāḥ pakvaphalāśayā madhukarīś cumbanti muñcanti ca /
analyzed: jambūnām kusuma udareṣu ati rasāt ābaddha pāna utsavāḥ kīrāḥ pakva phala āśayāḥ madhukarīḥ cumbanti muñcanti ca
translated: The cuckoos, having drunk to their heart's content from the interior of the mango blossoms, kiss and release the honeybees, hoping for ripe fruit.

original: eteṣām api paśya kiṃśukataroḥ patrair abhinnatviṣāṃ puṣpabhrāntibhir āpatanti sahasā cañcūṣu bhṛṅgāṅganāḥ // / //
analyzed: eteṣām api paśya kiṃśuka taroḥ patraiḥ abhinna tviṣām puṣpa bhrāntibhiḥ āpatanti sahasā cañcūṣu bhṛṅga aṅganāḥ  /
translated: See, even in the case of these [bees], the female bees suddenly alight on the beaks, mistaking the leaves of the kinshuka tree, which have the same color as its flowers.

original: rājaśekharasya
analyzed: rājaśekharasya
translated: Of Rajashekhara

original: dṛśyante madhumattakokilavadhūnirdhūtacūtāṅkura prāgbhāraprasaratparāgasikatādurgās taṭībhūmayaḥ /
analyzed: dṛśyante madhu matta kokila vadhū nirdhūta cūta aṅkura prāgbhāra prasarat parāga sikatā durgāḥ taṭī bhūmayaḥ
translated: The river banks are seen to be impassable due to the sand-like pollen spreading from the clusters of mango buds shaken by the intoxicated female cuckoos.

original: yāḥ kṛcchrād abhilaṅghya lubdhakabhayāt tair eva reṇūtkarair dhārāvāhibhir asti luptapadavīniḥśaṅkam eṇīkulam // / //
analyzed: yāḥ kṛcchrāt abhilaṅghya lubdhaka bhayāt taiḥ eva reṇu utkaraiḥ dhārā vāhibhiḥ asti lupta padavī niḥśaṅkam eṇī kulam  /
translated: The herd of deer, which had to jump over the snow with difficulty, is now fearlessly moving along the path cleared by the falling snow.

original: murāreḥ🔽aśithilaparispandaḥ kunde tathaiva madhuvrato nayanasuhṛdo vṛkṣāś caite na kuḍmalaśālinaḥ /
analyzed: murāreḥ  aśithila parispandaḥ kunde tathā eva madhuvrataḥ nayana suhṛdaḥ vṛkṣāḥ ca ete na kuḍmala śālinaḥ
translated: Of Murari🔽The bee is as active as ever on the jasmine flower, and these trees, friends to the eyes, are not bearing buds.

original: dalati kalikā cautī nāsmiṃs tathā mṛgacakṣuṣām atha ca hṛdaye mānagranthiḥ svayaṃ śithilāyate // / //
analyzed: dalati kalikā cautī nā asmin tathā mṛga cakṣuṣām atha ca hṛdaye māna granthiḥ svayam śithilāyate  /
translated: The bud of the mango tree does not blossom so much for the eyes of the deer, but the knot of pride in the heart loosens itself.

original: kāntāṃ hitvā virahavidhurārambhakhedālasāṅgīṃ mām ullaṅghya vrajatu pathikaḥ kāpi yady asti śaktiḥ /
analyzed: kāntām hitvā viraha vidhura ārambha kheda alasa aṅgīm mām ullaṅghya vrajatu pathikaḥ kā api yadi asti śaktiḥ
translated: If the traveler has the power to leave his beloved, who is languid with fatigue from the difficult task of separation, and to pass over me, let him go.

original: ity āśokī jagati sakale vallarī cīrikeva prāptārambhe kusumasamaye kāladevena dattā // / //
analyzed: iti āśokī jagati sakale vallarī cīrikā iva prāpta ārambhe kusuma samaye kāladevena dattā  /
translated: Thus, in the entire world, the creeper is like a notice board, given by the god of love at the time of the arrival of the flower season.

original: mandaṃ dakṣiṇam āhvayanti pavanaṃ puṃskokilavyāhṛtaiḥ saṃskurvanti vanasthalīḥ kisalayottaṃsair niṣaṇṇālibhiḥ /
analyzed: mandam dakṣiṇam āhvayanti pavanam puṃskokila vyāhṛtaiḥ saṃskurvanti vana sthalīḥ kisalaya uttaṃsaiḥ niṣaṇṇa ālibhiḥ
translated: Gently inviting the southern wind with the cooings of the male cuckoos, they are adorning the forest regions with bees seated on the sprouts as ornaments.

original: candraṃ sundarayanti muktatuhinaprāvārayā jyotsnayā vardhante ca vivardhayanti ca muhus te 'mī smaraṃ vāsarāḥ // / //
analyzed: candram sundarayanti mukta tuhina prāvārayā jyotsnayā vardhante ca vivardhayanti ca muhur te mī smaram vāsarāḥ
translated: The days, with their moonlight that has cast off the covering of snow, beautify the moon, and they increase and again and again make to grow that Cupid.

original: hṛdyasnigdhaiḥ parabhṛtarutair muktadīrghapravāsaḥ pratyāvṛtto madhur iti vadan dakṣiṇo gandhavāhaḥ /🔽śiñjallolabhramaravalayaḥ kānanālīvadhūnāṃ sadyaḥ kundasmitabṛhatikāḥ pūrṇapātrīkaroti // / //
analyzed: hṛdi asnigdhaiḥ parabhṛta rutaiḥ mukta dīrgha pravāsaḥ pratyāvṛttaḥ madhuḥ iti vadan dakṣiṇaḥ gandhavāhaḥ  śiñjat lola bhramara valayaḥ kānana ālī vadhūnām sadyas kunda smita bṛhatikāḥ pūrṇapātrīkaroti  /
translated: The southern breeze, having been away for a long time, has returned, announcing the arrival of spring, with the sweet and affectionate cooings of the cuckoos.🔽The jasmine creeper, with its bracelets of swinging bees, immediately makes a full cup of the large smiles of the young women of the forest.

original: lolaiḥ kokilamaṇḍalair madhulihāṃ caṃcūryamāṇair gaṇair nīrandhrair gṛhavāṭikāparisareṣv aṅgāritaiḥ kiṃśukaiḥ /
analyzed: lolaiḥ kokila maṇḍalaiḥ madhulihām caṃcūryamāṇaiḥ gaṇaiḥ nīrandhraiḥ gṛha vāṭikā parisareṣu aṅgāritaiḥ kiṃśukaiḥ
translated: With the circles of restless cuckoos, the swarms of honeybees being chased away, and the flame-trees in full bloom in the courtyards of the houses,

original: prārabdhe timire vasantasamayakṣoṇīpater bhrāmyataḥ prasnigdhā parito dhṛteva kalikādīpāvaliś campakaiḥ // / //
analyzed: prārabdhe timire vasanta samaya kṣoṇīpateḥ bhrāmyataḥ prasnigdhā paritas dhṛtā iva kalikā dīpa āvaliḥ campakaiḥ
translated: when the darkness has set in, the garland of campaka flowers, as if held all around, seems to be the lamp for the wandering king of the spring season.

original: manovinodasyaitau
analyzed: manaḥ vinodasya etau
translated: These two are by Manovijñāna.

original: cyutasumanasaḥ kundāḥ puṣpodgameṣv alasā drumā manasi ca giraṃ grathnantīme kiranti na kokilāḥ /
analyzed: cyuta sumanasaḥ kundāḥ puṣpa udgameṣu alasāḥ drumāḥ manasi ca giram grathnanti ime kiranti na kokilāḥ
translated: The jasmine flowers have fallen, the trees are languid in putting forth flowers, and these cuckoos, though forming words in their minds, do not utter them.

original: atha ca savituḥ śītollāsaṃ lunanti marīcayo na ca jaṭharatām ālambante klamodayadāyinīm // / //🔽sāmyaṃ samprati sevate vicakilaṃ ṣāṇmāsikair mauktikair bāhlīkīdaśanavraṇāruṇatalaiḥ patrair aśoko 'rcitaḥ /
analyzed: atha ca savituḥ śīta ullāsam lunanti marīcayaḥ na ca jaṭhara tām ālambante klama udaya dāyinīm  / sāmyam samprati sevate vicakilam ṣāṇmāsikaiḥ mauktikaiḥ vāhlīkī daśana vraṇa aruṇa talaiḥ patraiḥ aśokaḥ rcitaḥ
translated: And yet the sun's rays draw out the cool moisture, but do not resort to the state of the stomach, which brings about the rise of fatigue.🔽Now the Aśoka tree is worshipped with the leaves of the six-month old pearls, which are red at the base like the wounds of the teeth of a Bahlīkī woman.

original: bhṛṅgālaṅghitakoṭi kiṃśukam idaṃ kiṃcid vivṛntāyate māñjiṣṭhair mukulaiś ca pāṭalitaror anyaiva kācil lipiḥ // / //
analyzed: bhṛṅga ālaṅghita koṭi kiṃśukam idam kiṃcid vivṛntāyate māñjiṣṭhaiḥ mukulaiḥ ca pāṭali taroḥ anyā eva kācid lipiḥ  /
translated: This Kiṃśuka tree, whose tips are not touched by bees, slightly opens up. And on the other Pāṭala tree, there is some other kind of writing with its reddish buds.

original: garbhagranthiṣu vīrudhāṃ sumanaso madhye 'ṅkuraṃ pallavā vāñchāmātraparigrahaḥ pikavadhūkaṇṭhodare pañcamaḥ /
analyzed: garbhagranthiṣu vīrudhām sumanasaḥ madhye ṅkuram pallavāḥ vāñchā mātra parigrahaḥ pika vadhū kaṇṭha udare pañcamaḥ
translated: In the joints of the creepers, there are flowers; in the middle, there are sprouts and leaves; in the throat of the female cuckoo, the fifth note is retained only as a desire.

original: kiṃ ca trīṇi jagani jiṣṇu divasair dvitrair manojanmano devasyāpi cirojjhitaṃ yadi bhaved abhyāsavaśyaṃ dhanuḥ // / //
analyzed: kim ca trīṇi jagani jiṣṇu divasaiḥ dvitraiḥ manaḥ janmanaḥ devasya api cira ujjhitam yadi bhavet abhyāsa vaśyam dhanuḥ  /
translated: And moreover, the three worlds are conquered by the god of love in two or three days, if his bow, long abandoned, were to become subject to practice, even for the god.

original: rājaśekharasyaitau
analyzed: rājaśekharasya etau
translated: These are by Rājaśekhara.

original: śītās tair iva bhagnaśaiśiraniśābhāgair ahaḥ sphāyate garbhaṃ bibhrati kiṃśukā iva diśāṃ tāpāya vahnyaṅkuram /
analyzed: śītāḥ taiḥ iva bhagna śaiśira niśā bhāgaiḥ ahar sphāyate garbham bibhrati kiṃśukāḥ iva diśām tāpāya vahni aṅkuram
translated: The day expands with those parts of the cold night of Śaśin (the moon) as if broken by them, and the Kiṃśuka trees bear a fetus, a fire-sprout, for the torment of the quarters.

original: kiṃ ca svāśrayasambhṛtaprathimasu cchāyātapāṅgeṣv ayaṃ lokaḥ stokaraso 'dya na kvacid api svacchandam ānandati // / //
analyzed: kim ca sva āśraya sambhṛta prathimasu chāyā ātapa aṅgeṣu ayam lokaḥ stoka rasaḥ na kvacid api svacchandam ānandati  /
translated: Moreover, this world, in the shadows and warmth of its own abode, today finds no joy anywhere at its own will, with a taste for mere morsels.

original: trilocanasya
analyzed: tri locanasya
translated: Of Trilocana

original: udbhinnastabakāvataṃsasubhagāḥ preṅkhanmarunnartitāḥ puṣpodgīrṇaparāgapāṃśulalasatpatraprakāṇḍatviṣaḥ /
analyzed: udbhinna stabaka avataṃsa subhagāḥ preṅkhat marut nartitāḥ puṣpa udgīrṇa parāga pāṃśu lalasat patra prakāṇḍa tviṣaḥ
translated: The trees are delightful with buds and garlands, swaying in the gentle breeze, their stems and leaves shining with pollen from the flowers.

original: gambhīrakramapañcamonmadapikadhvānocchaladgītayaḥ pratyujjīvitamanmathotsava iva krīḍanty amū bhūruhaḥ // / //
analyzed: gambhīra krama pañcama unmada pika dhvāna ucchalat gītayaḥ pratyujjīvita manmatha utsave iva krīḍanti amū bhūruhaḥ  /
translated: With songs rising from the deep-throated fifth note of maddened cuckoos, they seem to be playing as if the festival of love has been revived.

original: prāg eva jaitram astraṃ sahakāralatā smarasya cāpabhṛtaḥ /
analyzed: prāk eva jaitram astram sahakāra latā smarasya cāpa bhṛtaḥ
translated: Even before, the mango vine was victorious as an arrow of Cupid, the wielder of the bow.

original: kiṃ punar analpanipatitamadhukaraviṣakalkalepena // / //
analyzed: kim punar analpa nipatita madhukara viṣa kalka lepena
translated: What to speak of it now, smeared with the paste of the poison of bees that have fallen in large numbers?

original: śubhāṅgasya🔽svasti śrīmalayācalāt smarasakhaḥ śrīmān vasantānilaḥ krīḍāveśmasu kāminaḥ kuśalayaty etac ca vaktītarat /
analyzed: śubha aṅgasya  svasti śrī malaya acalāt smarasakhaḥ śrīmān vasanta anilaḥ krīḍā veśmasu kāminaḥ kuśalayati etat ca vakti itarat
translated: Of Shubhaṅga🔽May the auspicious spring breeze, the friend of Cupid, dwelling in the pleasure houses of lovers, be auspicious, and say this:

original: eṣo 'haṃ muditālikokilakulaṃ kurvan vanaṃ prāptavān yuṣmābhiḥ priyakāminīparigataiḥ sthātavyam asmād iti // / //
analyzed: eṣaḥ ham mudita ali kokila kulam kurvan vanam prāptavān yuṣmābhiḥ priya kāminī parigataiḥ sthātavyam asmāt iti
translated: I have come to the forest, making the flocks of cuckoos and peacocks joyful. You who are occupied with your beloveds should stay here.

original: ete nūtanacūtakorakaghanagrāsātirekībhavat kaṇṭhadhvānajuṣo haranti hṛdayaṃ madhyevanaṃ kokilāḥ /
analyzed: ete nūtana cūta koraka ghana grāsa ati rekībhavat kaṇṭha dhvāna juṣaḥ haranti hṛdayam madhye vanam kokilāḥ
translated: These cuckoos in the middle of the forest, their throat-sounds intensified by the excess of eating the dense buds of the new mango blossoms, captivate the heart.

original: yeṣām akṣinibhena bhānti bhagavadbhūteśanetrānala jvālājālakarālitāsamaśarāṅgārasphuliṅgā ime // / //
analyzed: yeṣām akṣi nibhena bhānti bhagavat bhūteśa netra anala jvālā jāla karālita asamaśara aṅgāra sphuliṅgāḥ ime  /
translated: Whose eyes are terrible with a network of flames from the eye of the Lord Shiva, like the sparks from the burning coals of the god of love.

original: kiṃśukakalikāntargatacandrakalāsphardhi keśaraṃ bhāti /
analyzed: kiṃśuka kalikā antargata candra kalā sphardhi keśaram bhāti
translated: The filaments shine like the digit of the moon hidden within the bud of the kinshuka tree.

original: raktanicolakapihitaṃ dhanur iva jatumudritaṃ vitanoḥ // / //
analyzed: rakta nicolaka pihitam dhanuḥ iva jatu mudritam vitanoḥ  /
translated: It is as if the bow of the Creator, covered with a red garment, is being stretched.

original: vallaṇasya
analyzed: vallaṇasya
translated: Of Vallana

original: vāpyo danturitodarāḥ kamalinīpatrāṅkuragranthibhiś cūtānāṃ kalikāmilanmadhulihāṃ kāpi sthitir vartate /
analyzed: vāpyaḥ danturita udarāḥ kamalinī patra aṅkura granthibhiḥ cūtānām kalikā milat madhulihām kā api sthitiḥ vartate
translated: The ponds have their bellies covered with moss, and there is a certain condition of the mango buds with the swarms of honeybees clinging to them.

original: daurbhāgyopanayāya sāmpratamayām alpo 'pi mārgaśramaḥ śikṣām ullalituṃ dadāti rajasāṃ gantrīpathe mārutaḥ // / //
analyzed: daurbhāgya upanayāya sāmprata mayām alpaḥ pi mārga śramaḥ śikṣām ullalitum dadāti rajasām gantrīpathe mārutaḥ  /
translated: Now, for the sake of bringing about misfortune, even a little fatigue from traveling on the road causes the wind on the highway of the women to rise up to play.

original: NB Ingalls conjectures tentatively sampravasatām for sāmpratamayām in c /
analyzed: conjectures tentatively sampravasatām for sāmpratamayām in c
translated: N. B. Ingalls tentatively conjectures sampravasatām for sāmpratam ayām in c.

original: abhinandasya
analyzed: abhinandasya
translated: Of Abhinanda

original: āraktair navapallavair viṭapino netrotsavaṃ tanvate tān dhunvann ayam abhyupaiti madhurāmodo marud dakṣiṇaḥ /
analyzed: āraktaiḥ nava pallavaiḥ viṭapinaḥ netra utsavam tanvate tān dhunvan ayam abhyupaiti madhura āmodaḥ marut dakṣiṇaḥ
translated: The trees, with their reddish new sprouts, are giving a feast to the eyes. Shaking them, this southern wind, fragrant with honey, is approaching.

original: tenāliṅgitamātra eva vidhivat prādurbhavan nirbhara krīḍākūtakaṣāyitena manasā loko 'yam unmādyate // / //🔽kāpy anyā mukulādhikāramilitā lakṣmīr aśokadrume mākandaḥ samayocitena vidhinā dhatte 'bhijātaṃ vapuḥ /
analyzed: tena āliṅgita mātraḥ eva vidhivat prādurbhavan nirbhara krīḍā ākūta kaṣāyitena manasā lokaḥ yam unmādyate  /   kā api anyā mukula adhikāra militā lakṣmīḥ aśoka drume mākandaḥ samaya ucitena vidhinā dhatte bhijātam vapuḥ
translated: As soon as it embraces him, as is proper, with a mind reddened by the desire to play intensely, this world becomes intoxicated.🔽There is another Lakshmi, united with the authority over the buds, in the Asoka tree. The mango tree bears an excellent form according to the proper rite.

original: kiṃ cāṣāḍhagirer anaṅgavijayaprastāvanāpaṇḍitaḥ svairaṃ sarpati bālacandanalatālīlāsakho mārutaḥ // / //
analyzed: kim ca āṣāḍha gireḥ anaṅga vijaya prastāvanā paṇḍitaḥ svairam sarpati bāla candana latā līlā sakhaḥ mārutaḥ
translated: Moreover, the wind, the friend of the sport of the young sandal tree, moves freely, the herald of the victory of Cupid on the mountain of Ashadha.

original: vahnir manye himajalamiṣāt saṃśritaḥ kiṃśukeṣu śyāmaṃ dhūmaiḥ sa khalu kurute kānanaṃ korakākhyaiḥ /
analyzed: vahniḥ manye hima jala miṣāt saṃśritaḥ kiṃśukeṣu śyāmam dhūmaiḥ sa khalu kurute kānanam koraka ākhyaiḥ
translated: I think the fire, mistaking the water of snow, has resorted to the Kinsuka trees. Indeed, it makes the forest dark with its flames called Kora.

original: saṃtāpārthaṃ katham itarathā pānthasīmantinīnāṃ puṣpavyājād visṛjati śikhāśreṇim udgāḍhaśoṇīm // / //
analyzed: saṃtāpa artham katham itarathā pāntha sīmantinīnām puṣpa vyājāt visṛjati śikhā śreṇim udgāḍha śoṇīm  /
translated: How else would it, for the sake of heating the women of travelers, release a deep red row of flames under the pretext of flowers?

original: pautāyaneḥ🔽varśyāmaṃ/lem
analyzed: pautāyaneḥ  varśyā amaṃlem
translated: of Pautayaneya🔽green🔽conjunction

original: conj/ /Ingalls / vyāmaṃ /edKG
analyzed: c un in ga l s vi ā mam e k g
translated: a fathom

original: śroṇyāṃ citraḥ kurubakaguṇaḥ karṇayor mugdhacūtaṃ raktāśokaṃ praṇayi kucayor mādhavī mūrdhajeṣu /
analyzed: śroṇyām citraḥ kuru baka guṇaḥ karṇayoḥ mugdha cūtam rakta aśokam praṇayi kucayoḥ mādhavī mūrdhajeṣu
translated: On the hips, a variegated Kurubaka flower; on the ears, a tender mango blossom; on the breasts, a red Ashoka flower; on the hair, a Madhavi creeper.

original: sarvāṅgīṇo bakularajasā piñjareṇoparāgaḥ straiṇo yūnāṃ bhavatu rataye veśasarvābhisāraḥ // / //
analyzed: sarvāṅgīṇaḥ bakula rajasā piñjareṇa uparāgaḥ straiṇaḥ yūnām bhavatu rataye veśa sarva abhisāraḥ  /
translated: May the whole-body decoration of the young men, with the reddish dust of Bakula flowers, be a complete conquest for their enjoyment.

original: sāvarṇeḥ🔽mughātāmrair navakiśalayaiḥ sambhṛtodāraśobhaṃ prādurbhūtabhramarasaraṇīyauvanodbhedacihnam /
analyzed: sāvarṇeḥ  mughā tāmraiḥ nava kiśalayaiḥ sambhṛta udāra śobham prādurbhūta bhramara saraṇī yauvana udbheda cihnam
translated: Of Savarni🔽The month, a friend of the flower-bowed Cupid, is filled with fresh coppery sprouts, bearing the mark of the onset of youth with the flight of bees.

original: sīmantinyaḥ kusumadhanuṣā baddhasakhyasya māsaḥ snigdhāsmerair mukham adhiguṇaṃ dṛṣṭipātaiḥ pibanti // / //
analyzed: sīmantinyaḥ kusuma dhanuṣā baddha sakhyasya māsaḥ snigdha asmeraiḥ mukham adhiguṇam dṛṣṭi pātaiḥ pibanti  /
translated: The young women, with their hair parted, drink the face of the month with sidelong glances, affectionate and smiling, enhancing its beauty.

original: vāgurasya🔽śikīmukhair adya manojñapakṣair viṣopalepād iva kajjalābhaiḥ /
analyzed: vāgurasya  śikīmukhaiḥ adya manojña pakṣaiḥ viṣa upalepāt iva kajjala ābhaiḥ
translated: Of Vagura🔽Today, the Mucukunda buds, with their charming petals, dark like collyrium, as if from the poison of the mountain,

original: nitāntapūrṇā mucakundakoṣā vibhānti tūṇā iva manmathasya // / //
analyzed: nitānta pūrṇāḥ muca kunda koṣāḥ vibhānti tūṇāḥ iva manmathasya
translated: Shine like the quiver of the god of love, completely filled.

original: śubhāṅgasya
analyzed: śubha aṅgasya
translated: Of Shubhaṅga

original: snehaṃ sravanti taravaḥ pañcāpi kṣipati mārgaṇān madanaḥ /
analyzed: sneham sravanti taravaḥ pañca api kṣipati mārgaṇān madanaḥ
translated: The trees ooze affection, and Cupid shoots his arrows.

original: parimuktakaṇṭharodhaḥ parapuṣṭaḥ kṣarati mādhuryam // / //
analyzed: parimukta kaṇṭha rodhaḥ parapuṣṭaḥ kṣarati mādhuryam
translated: The cuckoo, freed from the obstruction of its throat, coos sweetness.

original: śrīdharmākarasya
translated: Of Śrī Dharmakara

original: saṃkucitā iva pūrvaṃ durvāratuṣārajanitajaḍimānaḥ /
analyzed: saṃkucitāḥ iva pūrvam durvāra tuṣāra janita jaḍimānaḥ
translated: The days, which were previously contracted as if, their stiffness produced by the unbearable frost,

original: sampraty uparamati hime kramaśo divasāḥ prasārajuṣaḥ // / //
analyzed: samprati uparamati hime kramaśas divasāḥ prasāra juṣaḥ
translated: now gradually cease to be cold, as the days, eager to expand, are on the wane.

original: śrīdharaṇīdharasya🔽duḥśliṣṭadurlakṣyapalāśasaṃdhīny āpāṭalāgrāṇi harinti mūle /
analyzed: śrī dharaṇīdharasya  duḥśliṣṭa durlakṣya palāśa saṃdhīni āpāṭala agrāṇi harinti mūle
translated: Of Sri Dharanidhara🔽The fresh buds of the white lilies, with their joints difficult to discern and their tips not fully open, and green at the base,

original: kuśeśayānāṃ śukaśāvabhāṃsi prādurbabhūvur navakuḍmalāni // / //🔽upanayati kapole lolakarṇapravāla kṣaṇamukulaniveśāndolanavyāpṛtānām /
analyzed: kuśeśayānām śuka śāva bhāṃsi prādurbabhūvuḥ nava kuḍmalāni  upanayati kapole lola karṇa pravāla kṣaṇa mukula niveśa āndolana vyāpṛtānām
translated: resembling young parrots, have appeared.🔽The sun now brings forth on the cheeks of the Dravidian women drops of sweat, mixed with yellow sandal paste, and bitter with their fresh nail marks,

original: parimalitaharidrān samprati drāviḍīnāṃ navanakhapadatiktān ātapaḥ svedabindūn // / //
analyzed: parimalita haridrān samprati drāviḍīnām nava nakha pada tiktān ātapaḥ sveda bindūn  /
translated: while their ears are busy with the swaying of the fresh buds.

original: yogeśvarasya
analyzed: yogeśvarasya
translated: Of Yogesvara

original: sadyas tapto bhramati rajanīṃ vāsaraḥ khaṇḍayitvā kṣīṇakṣīṇā tadanu bhajate sāpi samyakprasādam /
analyzed: sadyas taptaḥ bhramati rajanīm vāsaraḥ khaṇḍayitvā kṣīṇa kṣīṇā tadanu bhajate sā api samyak prasādam
translated: The day, heated all of a sudden, wanders about, having cut short the night; and then that night too, being completely exhausted, attains complete grace.

original: eko loke kathayati narasyeṣṭajāte nisargaṃ nāryāḥ puṃsi sthitim anuguṇāṃ śaṃsati spaṣṭam anyā // / //
analyzed: ekaḥ loke kathayati narasya iṣṭa jāte nisargam nāryāḥ puṃsi sthitim anuguṇām śaṃsati spaṣṭam anyā  /
translated: One person in the world clearly declares the natural disposition of a man towards his beloved; another speaks of the woman's favorable disposition towards the man.

original: idānīṃ plakṣāṇāṃ jaṭharadalaviśleṣacaturaḥ sthitīnām ābandhaḥ sphuṭati śukacañcūpuṭanibhaḥ /
analyzed: idānīm plakṣāṇām jaṭhara dala viśleṣa caturaḥ sthitīnām ābandhaḥ sphuṭati śuka cañcū puṭa nibhaḥ
translated: Now the buds of the fig trees, skilled in separating the belly-leaves, are clearly bursting forth, resembling the beaks of parrots.

original: tataḥ strīṇāṃ hanta kṣamam adharakāntiṃ kalayituṃ samantān niryāti sphuṭasubhagarāgaṃ kisalayam // / //🔽udgacchaty alijhaṃkṛtiḥ smaradhanur jyāmañjuguñjāravair niryātā viṣaliptabhalliviṣamāḥ kaṅkelliphullacchaṭāḥ /
analyzed: tatas strīṇām hanta kṣamam adhara kāntim kalayitum samantāt niryāti sphuṭa subhaga rāgam kisalayam  udgacchati ali jhaṃkṛtiḥ smaradhanuḥ jyā mañju guñjā ravaiḥ niryātāḥ viṣa lipta bhalli viṣamāḥ kaṅkel liphulla chaṭāḥ
translated: Then, alas, it is possible for the women to gauge the beauty of their lips all around, as the sprout comes forth with a clear and delightful hue.🔽The humming of bees rises up with the sweet twang of Cupid's bowstring, and the clusters of kankeLLI flowers, smeared with poison, are spread out.

original: re sampraty apavitram atra pathikāḥ sārambham ujjṛmbhate cūto dūta ivāntakasya kalikājālasphuratpallavaḥ // / //
analyzed: re samprati a pavitram atra pathikāḥ sa ārambham ujjṛmbhate cūtaḥ dūtaḥ iva antakasya kalikā jāla sphurat pallavaḥ
translated: Hey travelers, now the mango tree, like a messenger of death, with its sprouts flickering with clusters of buds, is fully blossoming here, impure as it is.

original: mithaḥkrīḍālolabhramarabharabhaṅgāṅkurarasa prasekapronmīlatparimalasamālabdhapavanaḥ /
analyzed: mithas krīḍā lola bhramara bhara bhaṅga aṅkura rasa praseka pronmīlat parimala samālabdha pavanaḥ
translated: The wind, perfumed by the oozing sap from the buds broken by the swarm of bees playfully buzzing together,

original: ito 'sty eṣa śrīmān aviralam idānīṃ mukulitaḥ prayacchann unmādān ahaha sahakāradrumayuvā // / //
analyzed: itas sti eṣa śrīmān aviralam idānīm mukulitaḥ prayacchan unmādān ahaha sahakāra druma yuvā
translated: Here is that glorious young mango tree, now constantly budded, giving rise to madness, alas!

original: aṅkurite pallavite korakite vikasite ca sahakāre /
analyzed: aṅkurite pallavite korakite vikasite ca sahakāre
translated: When the mango tree has sprouted, leafed out, budded, and blossomed,

original: aṅkuritaḥ pallavitaḥ korakito vikasitaś ca hṛdi madanaḥ // / //🔽utphullā navamālikā madayati ghrāṇendriyāhlādinī jātaṃ dhūsaram eva kiṃśukataror āśyāmalaṃ jālakam /
analyzed: aṅkuritaḥ pallavitaḥ korakitaḥ vikasitaḥ ca hṛdi madanaḥ  utphullā navamālikā madayati ghrāṇa indriya āhlādinī jātam dhūsaram eva kiṃśuka taroḥ ā śyāmalam jālakam
translated: Love has sprouted, put forth leaves, blossomed, and is now in full bloom in my heart.🔽The newly blossomed jasmine vine, delightful to the sense of smell, intoxicates; the ashy-gray mesh of the kinsuka tree has appeared.

original: ācinvanti kadambakāni madhunaḥ pāṇḍūni mattālayaḥ strīṇāṃ pīnaghanastaneṣu kaṇavān svedaḥ karoty āspadam // / //
analyzed: ācinvanti kadambakāni madhunaḥ pāṇḍūni matta ālayaḥ strīṇām pīna ghana staneṣu kaṇavān svedaḥ karoti āspadam  /
translated: The intoxicated bees are collecting pale pollen from the mango blossoms, and the sweat with pollen on the full, firm breasts of the women finds a place.

original: bhavabhūteḥ🔽sapadi sakhībhir nibhṛtaṃ virahavatīs trātum atra bhajyante /
analyzed: bhavabhūteḥ  sapadi sakhībhiḥ nibhṛtam virahavatīḥ trātum atra bhajyante
translated: Of Bhavabhuti

original: sahakāramañjarīṇāṃ śikhodgamagranthayaḥ prathame // / //
analyzed: sahakāra mañjarīṇām śikhā udgama granthayaḥ prathame
translated: The buds of the mango blossoms, which are like the knots in the rising flame, are quickly broken by the friends in secret to save the love-lorn women.

original: rājaśekharasya🔽Colo iti vasantavrajyā
analyzed: rājaśekharasya  iti vasantavrajyā
translated: Of Rajasekhara🔽Thus ends the section on spring in the Vasantavriksha of Bhoja.

original: grīṣmavrajyā//
analyzed: grīṣma vrajyā
translated: The section on summer

original: viśleṣo janitaḥ priyair api janair ujjṛmbhitaṃ nālikair mitreṇāpi kharāyitaṃ ratuṇayā dīrghāyitaṃ tṛṣṇayā /
analyzed: viśleṣaḥ janitaḥ priyaiḥ api janaiḥ ujjṛmbhitam nālikaiḥ mitreṇa api kharāyitam ratuṇayā dīrghāyitam tṛṣṇayā
translated: Separation is caused by even dear people, yawning is exhibited by friends, harshness is done by the season, and thirst is prolonged.

original: gurvī vallabhatā jaḍair adhigatā doṣākaraḥ sevyate hā kālaḥ kim ayaṃ kalir na hi na hi prāptaḥ sa gharmāgamaḥ // / //
analyzed: gurvī vallabha tā jaḍaiḥ adhigatā doṣa ākaraḥ sevyate hā kālaḥ kim ayam kaliḥ na hi na hi prāptaḥ sa gharma āgamaḥ
translated: Heavy affection is attained by the dull-witted, the moon is served, alas! what is this? Is it the Kali age? No, no, that hot season has not arrived.

original: tadātvasnātānāṃ malayarajasārdrārdravapuṣāṃ kacān bibhrāṇānāṃ daravikacamallīmukulinaḥ /
analyzed: tadātva snātānām malaya rajasā ārdra ārdra vapuṣām kacān bibhrāṇānām dara vikaca mallī mukulinaḥ
translated: The hair of the fawn-eyed women, who have just bathed and whose bodies are still wet with mountain dust, bearing the buds of jasmine flowers that are slightly open,

original: nidāghārkaploṣaglapitamahimānaṃ mṛgadṛśāṃ pariṣvaṅgo 'naṅgaṃ punar api śanair aṅkurayati // / //
analyzed: nidāgha arka ploṣa glapita mahimānam mṛga dṛśām pariṣvaṅgaḥ naṅgam punar api śanais aṅkurayati  /
translated: The embrace of the women slowly causes the god of love to sprout again, whose glory was withered by the scorching heat of the summer sun.

original: maṅgalārjunasya
analyzed: maṅgalārjunasya
translated: Of Mangalarjuna

original: pravṛddhatāpo divaso 'timātram atyartham eva kṣaṇadā ca tanvī /
analyzed: pravṛddha tāpaḥ timātram atyartham eva kṣaṇadā ca tanvī
translated: The day with intense heat is extremely long, and the night is very short.

original: ubhau virodhakriyayā vibhinnau jāyāpatī sānuśayāv iva staḥ // / //
analyzed: ubhau virodha kriyayā vibhinnau jāyā patī sa anuśayau iva staḥ  /
translated: Both are in conflict, like a married couple with resentment.

original: baṭoḥ
analyzed: baṭoḥ
translated: Of a young brahmin

original: sarvāśārudhi dagdhavīrudhi sadā sāraṅgabaddhakrudhi kṣāmakṣmāruhi mandam unmadhulihi svacchandakundadruhi /
analyzed: sarva āśā rudhi dagdha vīrudhi sadā sāraṅga baddha krudhi kṣāma kṣmā ruhi mandam unmadhulihi svacchanda kunda druhi
translated: In the month of Jyeshtha, when all desires are like burnt sprouts, the cuckoo is always angry, the trees are dry and withered, the bees hum slowly, and the jasmine trees grow at will.

original: śuṣyacchrotasi taptabhūmirajasi jvālāyamānāmbhasi jyeṣṭhe māsi kharārkatejasi kathaṃ pāntha vrajañ jīvasi // / //
analyzed: śuṣyat śrotasi tapta bhūmi rajasi jvālāyamāna ambhasi jyeṣṭhe māsi khara arka tejasi katham pāntha vrajam jīvasi  /
translated: When the streams are drying up, the dust on the heated ground is burning, and the water is boiling, O traveler, how do you live in the scorching heat of the midday sun?

original: bāṇasya
analyzed: bāṇasya
translated: Of Bana

original: gurur garbhārambhaḥ klamayati kalatraṃ balibhujaḥ samagroṣmā cūtaṃ pacati picumardaṃ ca divasaḥ /
analyzed: guruḥ garbha ārambhaḥ klamayati kalatram balibhujaḥ samagra ūṣmā cūtam pacati picumardam ca divasaḥ
translated: The heavy burden of pregnancy tires the wife, the entire heat of the day ripens the mango and the wood-apple tree,

original: idānīṃ nīhārastimitapavanaprītijanitāṃ niśāśeṣo nidrāṃ nudati paṭadhūmyāṭamukharaḥ // / //
analyzed: idānīm nīhāra stimita pavana prīti janitām niśā śeṣaḥ nidrām nudati paṭa dhūmyāṭa mukharaḥ
translated: Now the night-ending breeze, delightful with the fog-like mist, dispels the sleep born of the pleasure of the still wind.

original: rājaśekharasya
analyzed: rājaśekharasya
translated: Of King Shekhar.

original: sāndrakṣīṇapratatavitatacchinnabhugnonnatābhiḥ prāyaḥ kaśmīrajarucijuṣo dāvavahneḥ śikhābhiḥ /
analyzed: sāndra kṣīṇa pratata vitata chinna bhugna unnatābhiḥ prāyas kaśmīra ja ruci juṣaḥ dāva vahneḥ śikhābhiḥ
translated: With its flames mostly having the beauty of the Kashmir saffron, thick, thin, long, wide, cut, bent, and raised,

original: vāyuḥ saṃcāriṇa iva likhaty ānane digvadhūnāṃ dhūmodgārair agurupavanaiḥ sāntarān patrabhaṅgān // / //🔽hindolāmadhuropalālanarasaprītaprapāpālikā gītāvarjitamugdhavātahariṇaśreṇīparītāntikāḥ /🔽autsukyaṃ janayanti pānthapariṣadgharmāmbubindūtkara vyākṣepakṣamamandamandamaruto mārgasthalīpādapāḥ // / //
analyzed: vāyuḥ saṃcāriṇaḥ iva likhati ānane digvadhūnām dhūma udgāraiḥ aguru pavanaiḥ sāntarān patrabhaṅgān  / hindolā madhura upalālana rasa prīta prapā pālikāḥ gītā varjita mugdha vāta hariṇa śreṇī parīta antikāḥ  autsukyam janayanti pāntha pariṣad gharmāmbu bindu utkara vyākṣepa kṣama manda manda marutaḥ mārga sthalī pādapāḥ
translated: The wind, as if moving, draws on the faces of the quarters the leaf-designs of the incense from the black aloe groves, with intervals.🔽The trees on the roadside, with the rows of charming deer-like breezes attracted by the singing, and the vicinity surrounded by the series of charming deer-like breezes attracted by the singing,🔽And with the drops of sweat-water from the bodies of the groups of travelers, which are capable of distracting the slow and gentle breezes, cause eagerness.

original: cañcaccañcuguṇodaraiḥ śithilitaprāyāṃsam utpakṣmala nyañcatpakṣapuṭāvakāśaviramatpārśvoṣmabhir nīyate /
analyzed: cañcat cañcu guṇa udaraiḥ śithilita prāyāṃsam utpakṣmala nyañcat pakṣapuṭa avakāśa viramat pārśva ūṣmabhiḥ nīyate
translated: The bird is being carried away by the wings, with the tips of the beak and feathers mostly loosened, and with the heat of the sides ceasing due to the downward movement of the wings.

original: jaṅghākuñcanalabdhanīḍanibiḍāvaṣṭambhakaṣṭojjhita kṣepīyaḥpavanābhighātarabhasotkṣepair ahaḥ pakṣibhiḥ // / //🔽dhāsyaty adya sitātapatrasubhagaṃ sā rājahaṃsī śiśoḥ smerāmbhoruhavāsino 'pi śirasi snehena pakṣadvayam /
analyzed: jaṅghā ākuñcana labdha nīḍa nibiḍa avaṣṭambha kaṣṭa ujjhita kṣepīyaḥ pavana abhighāta rabhasa utkṣepaiḥ ahar pakṣibhiḥ  / dhāsyati adya sita ātapatra subhagam sā rājahaṃsī śiśoḥ śirasi snehena pakṣa dvayam
translated: The day-birds, with their wings of the swift wind from the blows of the wings, will cast off the difficulty of supporting themselves in the tight grip of the nest obtained by bending the legs.🔽Today, the white umbrella-like royal goose will lovingly place its two wings on the head of the young one, who resides in a smiling lotus, with a pleasant white umbrella.

original: tṛṣṇārtaḥ śukaśāvako 'pi sutanoḥ pīnastanāsaṅginīṃ muktāhāralatāṃ tadaṅkavasatis toyāśayā pāsyati // / //
analyzed: tṛṣṇā ārtaḥ śuka śāvakaḥ pi su tanoḥ pīna stana āsaṅginīm muktā hāra latām tad aṅka vasatiḥ toyāśayā pāsyati  /
translated: Even the thirsty young parrot, residing on her body, will drink the pearl necklace garland, which is attached to the full breasts of the beautiful woman, with the hope of water.

original: bhuvāṃ gharmārambhe pavanacalitaṃ tāpahataye paṭacchatrākāraṃ vahati gaganaṃ dhūlipaṭalam /
analyzed: bhuvām gharma ārambhe pavana calitam tāpa hataye paṭa chatra ākāram vahati gaganam dhūli paṭalam
translated: When the earth begins to heat up, the sky carries a dust-cloud in the form of a cloth-umbrella, shaken by the wind, to remove the heat.

original: amī mandārāṇāṃ davadahanasaṃdehitadhiyo na ḍhaukante pātuṃ jhaṭiti makarandaṃ madhulihaḥ // / //
analyzed: amī mandārāṇām dava dahana saṃdehita dhiyaḥ na ḍhaukante pātum jhaṭiti makarandam madhulihaḥ  /
translated: These bees, whose minds are doubtful about the forest fire of the mandara trees, do not immediately rush to drink the honey.

original: bhavabhūteḥ🔽apāṃ mūle līnaṃ kṣaṇaparicitaṃ candanarase mṛṇālīhārādau kṛtalaghupadaṃ candramasi ca /
analyzed: bhavabhūteḥ  apām mūle līnam kṣaṇa paricitam candana rase mṛṇālī hāra ādau kṛta laghu padam candramasi ca
translated: Of Bhavabhuti

original: muhūrtaṃ viśrāntaṃ sarasakadalīkānanatale priyākaṇṭhāśleṣe nivasati paraṃ śaityam adhunā // / //
analyzed: muhūrtam viśrāntam sarasa kadalī kānana tale priyā kaṇṭha āśleṣe nivasati param śaityam adhunā  /
translated: The supreme coolness now resides in the embrace of the beloved's neck, having briefly rested at the root of the waters, familiar for a moment in the sandalwood water, having taken a light step in the pearl necklace and other ornaments, and for a moment in the moon.

original: prāntāraktavilocanāñcaladarīvyagrālpamakṣībhaya prodbhūtobhayaśṛṅgakoṭivigalacchaivālavallīsakhaiḥ /🔽pāthobindubhir akṣisandhiṣu śanaiḥ saṃsicyamānaḥ sukhaṃ magno vāriṇi dūraniḥsahatayā nidrāyate sairibhaḥ // / //
analyzed: prānta ārakta vilocana añcala darī vyagra alpa makṣī bhaya prodbhūta ubhaya śṛṅga koṭi vigalat śaivāla vallī sakhaiḥ  pāthaḥ bindubhiḥ akṣi sandhiṣu śanais saṃsicyamānaḥ sukham magnaḥ vāriṇi dūra niḥsaha tayā nidrāyate sairibhaḥ
translated: The buffalo, with its eyes half-closed in sleep, is slowly sprinkled with drops of water from the tips of the moss-covered horns, and is happily dozing in the water, unable to move far.

original: tāpaṃ stamberamasya prakaṭayati karaḥ śīkaraiḥ kukṣum ukṣan paṅkāṅkaṃ palvalānāṃ vahati taṭavanaṃ māhiṣaiḥ kāyakāṣaiḥ /🔽uttāmyattālavaś ca pratapati taraṇāvāṃśavīṃ tāpatandrīm adridroṇīkuṭīre kuhariṇi hariṇārātayo yāpayatni // / //
analyzed: tāpam stamberamasya prakaṭayati karaḥ śīkaraiḥ kukṣum ukṣan paṅka aṅkam palvalānām vahati taṭa vanam māhiṣaiḥ kāya kāṣaiḥ  uttāmyat tālavaḥ ca pratapati taraṇau āṃśavīm tāpa tandrīm adri droṇī kuṭīre kuhariṇi hariṇa arātayaḥ yāpayatni  /
translated: The sun's rays, sprinkling water from the clouds, remove the heat of the forest-dwellers. The forest on the banks of the ponds, scratched by the buffaloes, bears the marks of mud.🔽The deer, agitated and restless, dispel the drowsiness caused by the sun's heat by moving about in the caves of the mountain valleys.

original: jātāḥ pānthanakhaṃpacāḥ pracayino gantrīpathe pāṃśavaḥ kāsārodaraśeṣam ambu mahiṣo mathnāti tāmyattimi /
analyzed: jātāḥ pānthana khaṃpacāḥ pracayinaḥ gantrī pathe pāṃśavaḥ kāsāra udara śeṣam ambu mahiṣaḥ mathnāti tāmyat timi
translated: The dust on the road, which was scratched by the hooves of the travelers, has accumulated. The buffalo, with its eyes rolling, is churning the remaining water in the pond.

original: dṛṣṭir dhāvati dhātakīvanam asṛktarṣeṇa tārakṣavī kaṇṭhān bibhrati viṣkirāḥ śaraśamīnīḍeṣu nāḍiṃdhamān // / //
analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ dhāvati dhātakī vanam asṛj tarṣeṇa tārakṣavī kaṇṭhān bibhrati viṣkirāḥ śara śamī nīḍeṣu na aḍiṃdhamān
translated: The she-jackals, with their eyes reddened by the desire to drink blood, are looking at the forest of Dhaki trees. The male partridges are carrying the young ones in their beaks, which are trembling in their throats.

original: bāṇasyaitau
analyzed: bāṇasya etau
translated: These are the verses of Bana.

original: subhagasalilāvagāhāḥ pāṭalisaṃsargasurabhivanavātāḥ /
analyzed: subhaga salila avagāhāḥ pāṭali saṃsarga surabhi vana vātāḥ
translated: The days are delightful with the cool water to bathe in, the fragrant forest breezes mingling with the pāṭala flowers,

original: pracchāyasulabhanidrā divasāḥ pariṇāmaramaṇīyāḥ // / //
analyzed: pracchāya sulabha nidrāḥ divasāḥ pariṇāma ramaṇīyāḥ
translated: and the pleasant sleep easily obtained in the shade, as the day comes to an end.

original: kālidāsasya
analyzed: kālidāsasya
translated: Of Kālidāsa

original: agre taptajalā nitāntaśiśirā mūle muhur bāhubhir vyāmathyoparataprapeṣu pathikair mārgeṣu madhyaṃdine /
analyzed: agre tapta jalāḥ nitānta śiśirāḥ mūle muhur bāhubhiḥ vyāmathya uparata prapeṣu pathikaiḥ mārgeṣu madhyaṃdine
translated: In front, the hot water is very cool, in the middle of the day, on the roads, where travelers have stopped pounding with their arms again and again.

original: ādhārāḥ plutabālaśaivaladalacchedāvakīrṇormayaḥ pīyante halamuktamagnamahiṣaprakṣobhaparyāvilāḥ // / //
analyzed: ādhārāḥ pluta bāla śaivala dala cheda avakīrṇa ūrmayaḥ pīyante hala mukta magna mahiṣa prakṣobha paryāvilāḥ  /
translated: The supports, with waves scattered with pieces of floating young moss, are drunk, agitated by the churning of buffaloes that have left the plow and sunk down.

original: yogeśvarasya🔽mṛdbhūyiṣṭhatayā gurūn pariharann āraṇyakān gomayān valmīkān upagūhati praśithilaṃ jvālābhir udbalvajān /
analyzed: yogeśvarasya  mṛd bhūyiṣṭha tayā gurūn pariharan āraṇyakān gomayān valmīkān upagūhati praśithilam jvālābhiḥ udbalva jān
translated: Of Yogeśvara🔽Avoiding the heavy forest cow dung cakes, mostly made of clay, he clings loosely to the anthills, with their flames scattered by the wind.

original: vahnir nīḍikiliñjasaṃcayasamutsiktaś caran kānane prasnigdhān iha viṣkirāṇḍakalalān ājyāśayā lumpati // / //
analyzed: vahniḥ nīḍi kiliñja saṃcaya samutsiktaḥ caran kānane prasnigdhān iha viṣkira aṇḍa kalalān ājya āśayā lumpati  /
translated: The fire, burning in the forest with a heap of straw nests nearby, destroys here the oily eggs and embryos of the partridges, hoping for ghee.

original: tasyaiva
analyzed: tasya eva
translated: Of the same

original: dūrībhūtaśarāri viklavabakaṃ saṃkrāntakāraṇḍavaṃ klāmyatkaṅkam acakravākam amilanmadgu prayātaplavam /
analyzed: dūrībhūta śarāri viklava bakam saṃkrānta kāraṇḍavam klāmyat kaṅkam a cakravākam a milat madgu prayāta plavam
translated: The flock of cranes has gone far away, the flock of herons is distressed, the ruddy geese have migrated, the storks are exhausted, the ducks have left in flocks, and the geese have departed.

original: kliṣṭakrauñcam adhārtarāṣṭram apatatkoyaṣṭi niṣṭīṭibhaṃ sīdatsārasamaprasaktakuraraṃ kālena jātaṃ saraḥ // / //
analyzed: kliṣṭa krauñcam a dhārtarāṣṭram apatat koyaṣṭi niṣṭīṭibham sīdat sārasam a prasakta kuraram kālena jātam saraḥ  /
translated: The lake, with its afflicted Krauñca birds, its fallen Adhārta birds, its Koyaṣṭis, its Niṣṭīṭibhas, its sinking Sārasa birds, and its continuous Kurara cries, has come into season.

original: tasyaiva
analyzed: tasya eva
translated: Of the same [poet]:

original: toyottīrṇāḥ śrayati kabarīḥ śekharaḥ saptalānāṃ śaityaṃ siñcaty upari kucayoḥ pāṭalākaṇṭhadāma /
analyzed: toya uttīrṇāḥ śrayati kabarīḥ śekharaḥ saptalānām śaityam siñcati upari kucayoḥ pāṭalā kaṇṭha dāma
translated: The crest of the Saptala flowers, having crossed the water, takes up the braids; it sprinkles the coolness on the breasts with the garland of the Pāṭalā flowers around the neck.

original: kāntaṃ karṇāv abhiniviśate komalāgraṃ śirīṣaṃ strīṇām aṅge vibhajati tapas tatra tatrātmacihnam // / //
analyzed: kāntam karṇau abhiniviśate komala agram śirīṣam strīṇām aṅge vibhajati tapaḥ tatra tatra ātma cihnam  /
translated: The tender-tipped Śirīṣa flower, dear to the ear, enters the ears; the women's bodies divide the penance there, here and there, their own marks.

original: madhuśīlasya🔽śukapatraharitakomalakusumaśaṭānāṃ śirīṣayaṣṭīnām /
analyzed: madhuśīlasya  śuka patra harita komala kusuma śaṭānām śirīṣa yaṣṭīnām
translated: Of Madhusīla:

original: talam āśrayati dinātapabhayena paripiṇḍitaṃ śaityam // / //
analyzed: talam āśrayati dina ātapa bhayena paripiṇḍitam śaityam
translated: The coolness, well-rounded, resorts to the base of the Śirīṣa creepers, with their clusters of tender, green, parrot-feathered flowers, out of fear of the sun's heat during the day.

original: vāgurasya🔽haranti hṛdayāni yacchravaṇaśītalā veṇavo yad arghati karambitā śiśiravāriṇā vāruṇī /
analyzed: vāgurasya  haranti hṛdayāni yat śravaṇa śītalāḥ veṇavaḥ yat karambitā śiśira vāriṇā vāruṇī
translated: Of Vāgūra:🔽The flutes, cool to the ears, captivate the heart; the Vāruṇī, mixed with cold water, is offered.

original: bhavanti ca himopamāḥ stanabhuvo yad eṇīdṛśāṃ śucer upari saṃsthito ratipateḥ prasādo guruḥ // / //
analyzed: bhavanti ca hima upamāḥ stana bhuvaḥ yat eṇī dṛśām śuceḥ upari saṃsthitaḥ ratipateḥ prasādaḥ guruḥ  /
translated: And the breasts of the doe-eyed women are like snow; the grace of Cupid, situated above the pure, is great.

original: jalārdrāḥ saṃvyānaṃ bisakisalayaiḥ kelivalayāḥ śirīṣair uttaṃso vicakilamayī hāraracanā /
analyzed: jala ārdrāḥ saṃvyānam bisa kisalayaiḥ keli valayāḥ śirīṣaiḥ uttaṃsaḥ vicakila mayī hāra racanā
translated: The garments are wet with water, the bracelets are made of lotus fibers, the head ornament is of shirisha flowers, and the necklace is made of vika chilas.

original: śucāv eṇākṣīṇāṃ malayajarasārdrāś ca tanavo vinā tantraṃ mantraṃ ratiramaṇamṛtyuṃjayavidhiḥ // / //
analyzed: śucau eṇa akṣīṇām malayaja rasa ārdrāḥ ca tanavaḥ vinā tantram mantram rati ramaṇa mṛtyuṃjaya vidhiḥ  /
translated: In the purity, the slender bodies of doe-eyed women are moist with the essence of sandalwood. Without the tantra and mantra, the method of conquering the god of love and death in love-making...

original: rajaniviramayāmeṣv ādiśantī ratecchāṃ kim api kaṭhinayantī nārikelīphalāmbhaḥ /
analyzed: rajani virama yāmeṣu ādiśantī rata icchām kim api kaṭhinayantī nārikelī phala ambhaḥ
translated: The night is ending, commanding the desire for love, making the coconut fruit water somehow hard.

original: api pariṇamayitrī rājarambhāphalānāṃ dinapariṇatiramyā vartate grīṣmalakṣmīḥ // / //
analyzed: api pariṇamayitrī rāja rambhā phalānām dina pariṇati ramyā vartate grīṣma lakṣmīḥ
translated: And turning the royal plantain fruits, the summer splendor, delightful in the change of day, continues...

original: ete rājaśekharasya
analyzed: ete rājaśekharasya
translated: These are of Rajashekhara

original: ambhodher jalayantramandiraparaspande 'pi nidrāṇayoḥ śrīnārāyaṇayor ghanaṃ vighaṭayaty ūṣmā samāliṅganam /
analyzed: ambhodheḥ jalayantra mandira para spande nidrāṇayoḥ śrī nārāyaṇayoḥ ghanam vighaṭayati ūṣmā samāliṅganam
translated: Even in the deep sleep of Shri Narayana and Narayana, when the ocean's water is motionless, the heat breaks their firm embrace.

original: kiṃ cottaptaviyatkalāpaphalake kaṅkālaśeṣaśriyaṃ candraṃ marmarayanti parpaṭam iva krūrā raver aṃśavaḥ // / //
analyzed: kim ca uttapta viyat kalāpa phalake kaṅkāla śeṣa śriyam candram marmarayanti parpaṭam iva krūrāḥ raveḥ aṃśavaḥ  /
translated: Moreover, the cruel rays of the sun make the moon, which has the beauty remaining as a skeleton on the hot canvas of the sky, murmur like a parpata.

original: nārāyaṇalaccheḥ🔽Colo iti grīṣmavrajyā
analyzed: nārāyaṇa laccheḥ  iti grīṣma vrajyā
translated: Of Narayana Lachcha🔽Thus ends the chapter on summer.

original: tataḥ prāvṛḍvrajyā
analyzed: tatas prāvṛṣ vrajyā
translated: Then begins the chapter on the rainy season.

original: vānīraprasavair nikuñjasaritām āsaktavāsaṃ payaḥ paryanteṣu ca yūthikāsumanasām ujjṛmbhitaṃ jālakaiḥ /🔽unmīlatkuṭajaprahāsiṣu girer ālambya sānūn itaḥ prāgbhāreṣu śikhaṇḍitāṇḍavavidhau meghair vitānāyyate // / //
analyzed: vānīra prasavaiḥ nikuñja saritām āsakta vāsam payaḥ paryanteṣu ca yūthikā sumanasām ujjṛmbhitam jālakaiḥ  unmīlat kuṭaja prahāsiṣu gireḥ ālambya sānūn itas prāgbhāreṣu śikhaṇḍita āṇḍava vidhau meghaiḥ vitānāyyate  /
translated: The water-bearing clouds, having their abode in the bowers of reeds on the banks of the forest streams, and spreading their nets of lightning in the Yūthikā flowers on the borders of the water,🔽having resorted to the slopes of the mountain, where the Kutaja trees are in full bloom, are being turned into canopies for the dancing of the peacocks in the eastern quarter.

original: phalabharapariṇāmaśyāmajambūnikuñja skhalitatanutaraṅgām uttareṇa śravantīm /
analyzed: phala bhara pariṇāma śyāma jambu nikuñja skhalita tanu taraṅgām uttareṇa śravantīm
translated: To the north of the river flowing with small waves slipping through the bower of Jambul trees dark with the ripening of their fruit,

original: uparivighaṭamānaprauḍhatāpiñjanīlaḥ śrayati śikharam adrer nūtanas toyavāhaḥ // / //🔽jṛmbhājarjaraḍimbaḍambaraghanaśrīmatkadambadrumāḥ śailābhogabhuvo bhavanti kakubhaḥ kādambinīśyāmalāḥ /🔽udyatkundalatāntaketakabhṛtaḥ kacchāḥ saricchrotasām āvirgandhaśilīndhralodhrakusumasmerā vanānāṃ gatiḥ // / //
analyzed: upari vighaṭamāna prauḍha tāpiñja nīlaḥ śrayati śikharam adreḥ nūtanaḥ toyavāhaḥ  / jṛmbhā jarjara ḍimba ḍambara ghana śrīmat kadamba drumāḥ śaila ābhoga bhuvaḥ bhavanti kakubhaḥ kādambinī śyāmalāḥ  udyat kunda latā anta ketaka bhṛtaḥ kacchāḥ sarit śrotasām āvis gandha śilīndhra lodhra kusuma smerā vanānām gatiḥ  /
translated: the new rain-bearing cloud, its tawny hue spreading upwards, is taking shelter on the peak of the mountain.🔽The directions, the slopes of the mountain, become dark with rain-clouds, with Kadamba trees thick with the loud humming of bees emerging from their eggs, their splendor dense.🔽The banks of the rivers, bearing the rising Kunda creepers and Ketaka flowers, are delightful with the fragrance of the Shirisha and Lodhra flowers.

original: utphullārjunasarvavāsitavahatpaurastyajhaṃjhāmarut preṅkholaskhalitendranīlaśakalasnigdhāmbudaśreṇayaḥ /
analyzed: utphulla arjuna sarva vāsita vahat paurastya jhaṃjhā marut preṅkhola skhalita indranīla śakala snigdha ambuda śreṇayaḥ
translated: The rows of clouds, dark with the water slipping from the swaying sapphire-like fragments, are fragrant with the pollen of the full-blown Arjuna flowers, borne by the eastern breeze.

original: dhārāsiktavasundharāsurabhayaḥ prāptās ta ete 'dhunā gharmāmbhovigamāgamavyatikaraśrīvāhino vāsarāḥ // / //
