original: sthalīnāṃ dagdhānām upari mṛgatṛṣṇānusaraṇāt tṛṣārtaḥ śāraṅgo viramati na khinne 'pi vapuṣi /
analyzed: sthalīnām dagdhānām upari mṛgatṛṣṇā anusaraṇāt tṛṣā ārtaḥ śāraṅgaḥ viramati na khinne vapuṣi
translated: The thirsty deer, though his body is tired, does not cease from following the mirage over the burnt-up ground.

original: ajānānas tattvaṃ na sa mṛgayate 'nyāṃ ca sarasīm abhūmau pratyāśā na hi phalati vighnaṃ ca kurute // / //
analyzed: a jānānaḥ tattvam na sa mṛgayate ca sarasīm abhūmau pratyāśā na hi phalati vighnam ca kurute  /
translated: Not knowing the truth, he does not seek another lake; for hope on barren ground bears no fruit, but only causes obstruction.

original: kiṃ kūrmasya bharavyathā na vapuṣi kṣmāṃ na kṣipaty eṣa yat kiṃ vā nāsti pariśramo dinakarasyāste na yan niścalaḥ /
analyzed: kim kūrmasya bhara vyathā na vapuṣi kṣmām na kṣipati eṣa yat kim vā nā asti pariśramaḥ dinakarasya āste na yat niścalaḥ
translated: Does the tortoise not bear a burden on his body? Why does he not throw himself on the ground? Or is not the sun tired? Why does he not rest?

original: kiṃ tv aṅgīkṛtam utsṛjan kṛpaṇavac chlāghyo jano lajjate nirvyūḍhiḥ pratipannavastuṣu satām ekaṃ batāho vratam // / //
analyzed: kim tu aṅgīkṛtam utsṛjan kṛpaṇa vat ślāghyaḥ janaḥ lajjate nirvyūḍhiḥ pratipanna vastuṣu satām ekam bata aho vratam  /  /
translated: But a man who, having promised, gives up, is shamed like a miser; that the good should carry out what they have undertaken is indeed their one vow.

original: svacchāśayo bhavati ko 'pi janaḥ prakṛtyā saṅgaḥ satām abhijanaś ca na hetur atra /
analyzed: su accha āśayaḥ bhavati kaḥ pi janaḥ prakṛtyā saṅgaḥ satām abhijanaḥ ca na hetuḥ atra
translated: Some man is pure-hearted by nature; association with the good and noble birth are not the cause here.

original: dugdhābdhilabdhajanano harakandharāsthaḥ svāṃ kālatāṃ tyajati jātu na kālakūṭaḥ // / //
analyzed: dugdhābdhi labdha jananaḥ hara kandhara sthaḥ svām kāla tām tyajati jātu na kālakūṭaḥ  /
translated: The Kālakūṭa poison, born from the milk-ocean, which rests on Śiva's throat, never abandons its own nature of being deadly.

original: vāsaś carma vibhūṣaṇaṃ śavaśiro bhikṣāṇatenāśanaṃ gaur ekaḥ sa ca lāṅgale 'py akuśalas tanmātrasāraṃ dhanam /
analyzed: vāsaḥ carma vibhūṣaṇam śava śiraḥ bhikṣā āṇatena aśanam gauḥ ekaḥ sa ca lāṅgale pi akuśalaḥ tad mātra sāram dhanam
translated: Your garment is skin, your ornament a human skull, your food begged for alms, your one possession a bull, and he is unskilled even in plowing; your wealth consists only of that.

original: śarvasyety avagamya yāti vimukhī ratnālayaṃ jāhvanī kaṣṭaṃ durgatikasya jīvitam aho dārair api tyajyate // / //
analyzed: śarvasya iti avagamya yāti vimukhī ratna ālayam jāhvanī kaṣṭam durgatikasya jīvitam aho dāraiḥ api tyajyate  /
translated: Knowing that you belong to Śiva, the goddess of the ocean of jewels turns away and goes elsewhere. Alas! The life of one in misfortune is abandoned even by his wife.

original: kaivartakarkaśakaragrahaṇacyuto 'pi jāle punar nipatitaḥ śapharo varākaḥ /
analyzed: kaivarta karkaśa kara grahaṇa cyutaḥ pi jāle punar nipatitaḥ śapharaḥ varākaḥ
translated: Even though thrown off by the rough hands of fishermen, the poor little fish falls back into the net.

original: daivāt tato 'pi galito gilito bakena vāme vidhau vada kathaṃ vyasanasya śāntiḥ // / //
analyzed: daivāt galitaḥ gilitaḥ bakena vāme vidhau vada katham vyasanasya śāntiḥ  /
translated: By chance, it escapes from there too, but is swallowed by a heron. When fate is adverse, tell me, how can misfortune be averted?

original: khanati na khuraiḥ kṣoṇīpṛṣṭhaṃ na nardati sādaraṃ prakṛtipuruṣaṃ dṛṣṭvaivāgre na kupyati gām api /
analyzed: khanati na khuraiḥ kṣoṇī pṛṣṭham na nardati sa ādaram prakṛti puruṣam dṛṣṭvā eva agre na kupyati gām api
translated: He does not dig the surface of the earth with his hooves, nor does he loudly bellow, nor does he get angry even at the cow in front of him, on seeing the natural male.

original: vahati tu dhuraṃ dhuryo dhairyād anuddhatakandharo jagati kṛtinaḥ kāryaudāryāt parān atiśerate // / //
analyzed: vahati tu dhuram dhuryaḥ dhairyāt anuddhata kandharaḥ jagati kṛtinaḥ kārya audāryāt parān atiśerate  /
translated: But the draught animal carries the load with patience, his neck not raised haughtily. In the world, the virtuous surpass others by the greatness of their deeds.

original: śiraḥ śārvaṃ svargāt paśupatiśirastaḥ kṣitibhṛtaṃ mahīdhrād uttuṅgād avanitalam asmāc ca jaladhim /
analyzed: śiraḥ śārvam svargāt paśupati śirastaḥ kṣitibhṛtam mahīdhrāt uttuṅgāt avani talam asmāt ca jaladhim
translated: The head of Shiva from heaven, the king from Shiva's head, the earth from the high mountain, and the ocean from the earth.

original: adho 'dho gaṅgāvad vayam upagatā dūram athavā padabhraṃśetānāṃ bhavati vinipātaḥ śatamukhaḥ // / //
analyzed: adhas dhas gaṅgā vat vayam upagatāḥ dūram athavā bhavati vinipātaḥ śata mukhaḥ  /
translated: We have gone far down like the Ganges, or else, the downfall of those who have lost their position is a hundredfold.

original: kvāpi kasya ca kuto 'pi kāraṇāc cittavṛttir iha kiṃ guṇāguṇaiḥ /
analyzed: kvāpi kasya ca kutas pi kāraṇāt citta vṛttiḥ iha kim guṇa aguṇaiḥ
translated: Somewhere, of someone, for some reason, what is the use of good or bad qualities in the functioning of the mind here?

original: unnataṃ yad avadhīrya bhūdharaṃ nīcam abdhim abhiyāti jāhnavī // / //
analyzed: unnatam yat bhūdharam nīcam abdhim abhiyāti jāhnavī
translated: Having disregarded the lofty mountain, the Ganges goes down to the low ocean.

original: sarasi bahuśas tārāchāyāṃ daśan parivañcitaḥ kumudaviṭapānveṣī haṃso niśāsu vicakṣaṇaḥ /
analyzed: sarasi bahuśas tārā chāyām daśan parivañcitaḥ kumuda viṭapa anveṣī haṃsaḥ niśāsu vicakṣaṇaḥ
translated: The wise swan, having seen the reflection of the stars many times in the lake, searching for the cluster of lilies at night, is deceived.

original: na daśati punas tārāśaṅkī divāpi sitotpalaṃ kuhakacakito lokaḥ satye 'py apāyam avekṣate // / //
analyzed: na daśati punar tārā āśaṅkī divā api sita utpalam kuhaka cakitaḥ lokaḥ satye pi apāyam avekṣate  /
translated: The deceitful world, suspecting a star, does not sting even a white lotus in the daytime, even if it sees danger in truth.

original: asthānābhiniveśī prāyo jaḍa eva bhavati no vidvān /
analyzed: a sthāna abhiniveśī prāyas jaḍaḥ eva bhavati no vidvān
translated: One who is attached to the impossible is mostly dull-witted, not learned.

original: bālād anyaḥ ko 'mbhasi jighṛkṣatīndoḥ sphuradbimbam // / //
analyzed: bālāt anyaḥ kaḥ mbhasi jighṛkṣati indoḥ sphurat bimbam
translated: Who other than a child would try to grasp the shining orb of the moon in water?

original: nirguṇam apy anuraktaṃ prāyo na samāśritaṃ jahati santaḥ /
analyzed: nirguṇam api anuraktam prāyas na samāśritam jahati santaḥ
translated: The good do not abandon even a qualityless but devoted person, mostly.

original: sahavṛddhikṣayabhājaṃ vahati śaśāṅkaḥ kalaṅkam api // / //
analyzed: saha vṛddhi kṣaya bhājam vahati śaśāṅkaḥ kalaṅkam api
translated: The moon bears the spot, which shares its growth and decay.

original: avikāriṇam api sajjanam aniśam anāryaḥ prabādhate 'tyartham /
analyzed: avikāriṇam api sat janam aniśam anāryaḥ prabādhate tyartham
translated: Even a good person who is unchanging is excessively troubled by a low person without end.

original: kamalinyā kim apakṛtaṃ himasya yas tāṃ sadā dahati // / //
analyzed: kamalinyā kim apakṛtam himasya yaḥ tām sadā dahati
translated: What harm has the lotus-plant done to snow, that it always burns it?

original: bhayaṃ yad dhanurīśvarasya śiśinā yaj jāmadagnyo hatas tyaktā yena guror girā vasumatī baddho yad ambhonidhiḥ /
analyzed: bhayam yat dhanuḥ īśvarasya śiśinā yat jāmadagnyaḥ hataḥ tyaktā yena guroḥ girā vasumatī baddhaḥ yat ambhonidhiḥ
translated: The fear of the lord of archers, the slaying of Jamadagni's son by the sharp one, the abandonment of the earth at the guru's word, the binding of the ocean -

original: ekaikaṃ daśakandharakṣayakṛto rāmasya kiṃ varṇyate daivaṃ varṇaya yena so 'pi sahasā nītaḥ kathāśeṣatām // / //
analyzed: ekaikam daśa kandhara kṣaya kṛtaḥ rāmasya kim varṇyate daivam varṇaya yena saḥ pi sahasā nītaḥ kathā śeṣa tām  /
translated: each of these is the cause of Rama's destruction of the ten-headed one. What is to be described? Describe fate, by which he too was suddenly reduced to a mere story.

original: śaśinam uditaṃ lekhāmātraṃ namanti na cetaraṃ gaganasaritaṃ dhatte mūrdhnā haro na nagātmajām /
analyzed: śaśinam uditam lekhā mātram namanti na ca itaram gagana saritam dhatte mūrdhnā haraḥ na naga ātmajām
translated: They bow to the rising moon, just a line, but not to the other, and Shiva does not hold the celestial Ganga on his head, but the daughter of the mountain.

original: tribhuvanapatir lakṣmīṃ tyaktvā hariḥ priyagopikaḥ paricitaguṇadveṣī loko navaṃ navam icchati // / //
analyzed: tribhuvana patiḥ lakṣmīm tyaktvā hariḥ priya gopikaḥ paricita guṇa dveṣī lokaḥ navam navam icchati  /
translated: Hari, the lord of the three worlds, abandons Lakshmi and becomes fond of cowherdesses. The world, hating familiar virtues, desires something new and new.

original: upaśamaphalād vidyābījāt phalaṃ dhanam icchatāṃ bhavati viphalaḥ prārambho yat tad atra kim adbhutam /
analyzed: upaśama phalāt vidyā bījāt phalam dhanam icchatām bhavati viphalaḥ prārambhaḥ yat tat atra kim adbhutam
translated: For those who desire wealth as the fruit from the seed of knowledge, which has the fruit of tranquility, the undertaking becomes fruitless. What wonder is there in that?

original: niyataviṣayāḥ sarve bhāvā na yānti hi vikriyāṃ janayitum alaṃ śāler bījaṃ na jātu javāṅkuram // / //
analyzed: niyata viṣayāḥ sarve bhāvāḥ na yānti hi vikriyām janayitum alam śāleḥ bījam na jātu java aṅkuram
translated: All things have fixed objects and do not undergo change. The seed of rice is capable of producing rice, but never a barley sprout.

original: tṛṣārtaiḥ śāraṅgaiḥ prati jaladharaṃ bhūri virutaṃ ghanair muktā dhārāḥ sapadi payasas tān prati muhuḥ /
analyzed: tṛṣā ārtaiḥ śāraṅgaiḥ prati jaladharam bhūri virutam ghanaiḥ muktāḥ dhārāḥ sapadi payasaḥ tān prati muhur
translated: The thirsty deer cry out to the rain clouds many times, and the clouds immediately release streams of water to them again and again.

original: khagānāṃ ke meghāḥ ka iva vihagā vā jalamucām ayācyo nārtānām anupakaraṇīyo na mahatām // / //
analyzed: khagānām ke meghāḥ ke iva vihagāḥ vā jalamucām a yācyaḥ na ārtānām an upakaraṇīyaḥ na mahatām  /
translated: To the birds, which are the clouds? And to the water-bearing clouds, which are the birds? The distressed do not beg the great, nor do the great refuse to help the distressed.

original: amarasiṃhasya
analyzed: amarasiṃhasya
translated: Of Amarasimha

original: payas tejo vāyur gaganam avanir viśvam api vā svayaṃ viṣṇus tasya tridaśajayinaḥ kiṃ na sukaram /
analyzed: payaḥ tejaḥ vāyuḥ gaganam avaniḥ viśvam api vā svayam viṣṇuḥ tasya tridaśa jayinaḥ kim na sukaram
translated: Water, fire, air, space, earth, or even the entire universe is Vishnu himself. What is not easy for that conqueror of the gods?

original: chalān nīto 'dhastād balir aṇukarūpeṇa tad api svabhāvāc cakrī yaḥ praguṇam api cakreṇa sṛjati // / //
analyzed: chalāt nītaḥ dhastāt baliḥ aṇuka rūpeṇa tat api svabhāvāt cakrī yaḥ praguṇam api cakreṇa sṛjati  /
translated: Though Bali was deceitfully brought down by him in the form of a dwarf, he created the world with his discus out of his own nature.

original: muṣṭikaraguhasya
analyzed: muṣṭi kara guhasya
translated: Of Mushtikaragupta

original: kiṃ nojjvalaḥ kim u kalāḥ sakalā na dhatte datte na kiṃ nayanayor mudam unmayūkhaḥ /
analyzed: kim nā ujjvalaḥ kim u kalāḥ sakalāḥ na dhatte datte na kim nayanayoḥ mudam unmayūkhaḥ
translated: Is not the moon bright? Does it not bear all the digits? Does it not give joy to the eyes?

original: rāhos tu cakrapatito 'stamito 'yam induḥ satyaṃ satām ahṛdayeṣu guṇās tṛṇāni // / //
analyzed: rāhoḥ tu cakra patitaḥ stamitaḥ yam induḥ satyam satām ahṛdayeṣu guṇāḥ tṛṇāni  /
translated: But this moon, fallen into Rahu's mouth and set, is truly a straw in the hearts of the good.

original: atulasya
analyzed: a tulasya
translated: Of Atulya

original: lūnās tilās tadanu śoṣam upāgatās te śoṣād dhi śuddhim atha tāpam upetavantaḥ /
analyzed: lūnāḥ tilāḥ tadanu śoṣam upāgatāḥ te śoṣāt hi śuddhim atha tāpam upetavantaḥ
translated: The sesame seeds were cut, then they became dry, from dryness they became pure, and then they attained heat.

original: tāpāt kaṭhoratarayantranipīḍanāni sneho nimittam iti duḥkhaparaṃparāyāḥ // / //🔽dugdha mugdham asti yas tvayā dhṛtaḥ sneha eṣa vipadekakāraṇam /
analyzed: tāpāt kaṭhoratara yantra nipīḍanāni snehaḥ nimittam iti duḥkha paraṃparāyāḥ  dugdha mugdham asti yaḥ tvayā dhṛtaḥ snehaḥ eṣa vipad eka kāraṇam
translated: From heat, they underwent the pressing of a very hard machine. Affection is the cause of this series of sufferings.🔽You have held this affection, which is innocent and milky, as the sole cause of calamity.

original: yatkṛte tvam apavāsitaṃ punaś chinnam unmathitam agnisākṛtam // / //
analyzed: yatkṛte tvam apavāsitam punar chinnam unmathitam agnisākṛtam
translated: For which you have been again starved, cut, uprooted, and burnt by fire.

original: mūrdhenduḥ parameśvareṇa vidhṛto vakro jaḍātmā kṣayī karṇānte ca parāpakāracaturo nyasto dvijihvādhipaḥ /
analyzed: mūrdha induḥ parameśvareṇa vidhṛtaḥ vakraḥ jaḍa ātmā kṣayī karṇa ante ca para apakāra caturaḥ nyastaḥ dvijihva adhipaḥ
translated: The moon on his head is held by the Supreme Lord, crooked, dull-witted, and perishable; and at the ear, the lord of serpents, skilled in harming others, is placed.

original: nandī dvāri bahiḥkṛto guṇanidhiḥ kaṣṭaṃ kim atrocyatāṃ pātrāpātravicāraṇāsv anipuṇaḥ prāyo bhaved īśvaraḥ // / //
analyzed: nandī dvāri bahis kṛtaḥ guṇa nidhiḥ kaṣṭam kim atra ucyatām pātra apātra vicāraṇāsu anipuṇaḥ prāyas bhavet īśvaraḥ  /
translated: Nandin is kept outside the door, and the treasure of virtues is made to suffer. What is to be said here? Mostly, the Lord is not skilled in discriminating between worthy and unworthy recipients.

original: kākutsthasya daśānano na kṛtavān dārāpahāraṃ yadi kvāmbhodhiḥ kva ca setubandhaghaṭanā kvottīrya laṅkājayaḥ /
analyzed: kākutsthasya daśānanaḥ na kṛtavān dāra apahāram yadi kva ambhodhiḥ kva ca setubandha ghaṭanā kva uttīrya laṅkā jayaḥ
translated: If Ravana had not abducted Sita, the wife of Rama, the son of Kakutstha, where would have been the construction of the bridge across the ocean, the conquest of Lanka after crossing it,

original: pārthasyāpi parābhavaṃ yadi ripur nādāt kva tādṛk tapo nīyante ripubhiḥ samunnatipadaṃ prāyaḥ paraṃ māninaḥ // / //
analyzed: pārthasya api parābhavam yadi ripuḥ nā adāt kva tādṛś tapaḥ nīyante ripubhiḥ samunnati padam prāyas param māninaḥ  /
translated: and the great penance of Arjuna, if his enemy had not given him defeat? Mostly, the enemies lead the proud ones to a high position.

original: śambūkāḥ kila nirgatā jalanidhes tīreṣu dāvāgninā dahyante maṇayo vaṇikkaratalair āyānti rājñāṃ śiraḥ /
analyzed: śambūkāḥ kila nirgatāḥ jalanidheḥ tīreṣu dāva agninā dahyante maṇayaḥ vaṇikkara talaiḥ āyānti rājñām śiraḥ
translated: The oysters, it is said, come out on the shores of the ocean and are burned by forest fires; the pearls are taken by merchants and come into the hands of kings.

original: sthānapracyutir alpakasya vipade santas tu deśāntaraṃ yānto yānti sadā samarpitaguṇāḥ ślāghyāḥ parām unnatim // / //
analyzed: sthāna pracyutiḥ alpakasya vipade santaḥ tu deśa antaram yāntaḥ yānti sadā samarpita guṇāḥ ślāghyāḥ parām unnatim  /
translated: The fall of a small person is a misfortune, but the good people go to another country and always attain great praise and high position by offering their good qualities.

original: ya eko lokānāṃ paramasuhṛd ānandajanakaḥ kalāśālī śrīmān nidhuvanavidhau maṅgalaghaṭaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ ekaḥ lokānām parama suhṛd ānanda janakaḥ kalā śālī śrīmān nidhuvana vidhau maṅgala ghaṭaḥ
translated: He who is the supreme friend of the worlds, the bringer of joy, skilled in the arts, glorious, the auspicious agent in the rites of love,

original: sudhāsūtiḥ so 'yaṃ tripuraharacūḍāmaṇir aho prayāty astaṃ hanta prakṛtiviṣamā daivagatayaḥ // / //
analyzed: sudhā sūtiḥ saḥ yam tripura hara cūḍāmaṇiḥ aho prayāti astam hanta prakṛti viṣamāḥ daiva gatayaḥ
translated: the source of nectar, the crest-jewel of the destroyer of Tripura - alas! He is setting, alas! The ways of fate are naturally uneven.

original: apetāḥ śatrubhyo vayam iti viṣādo 'yam aphalaḥ pratīkāras tv eṣām aniśam anusaṃdhātum ucitaḥ /
analyzed: apetāḥ śatrubhyaḥ vayam iti viṣādaḥ yam aphalaḥ pratīkāraḥ tu eṣām aniśam anusaṃdhātum ucitaḥ
translated: It is fruitless to despair, thinking We are safe from our enemies; rather, it is right to constantly plan their destruction.

original: jarāsaṃdhād bhagnaḥ saha halabhṛtā dānavaripur jaghānainaṃ paścān na kim anilasūnuḥ priyasakhaḥ // / //
analyzed: jarāsaṃdhāt bhagnaḥ saha halabhṛtā dānava ripuḥ jaghāna enam paścāt na kim anilasūnuḥ priya sakhaḥ
translated: Did the enemy of the demons, accompanied by the wielder of the plow, not later slay Jarasandha, his dear friend, the son of the wind god, after being defeated by him?

original: candraḥ kṣayī prakṛtivakratanur jaḍātmā doṣākāraḥ sphurati mitravipattikāle /
analyzed: candraḥ kṣayī prakṛti vakra tanuḥ jaḍa ātmā doṣa ākāraḥ sphurati mitra vipatti kāle
translated: The moon, which is decaying, naturally crooked in form, dull-minded, and appears in the form of a blemish,

original: mūrdhnā tathāpi vidhṛtaḥ parameśvareṇa naivāśriteṣu mahatāṃ guṇadoṣacintā // / //
analyzed: mūrdhnā tathā api vidhṛtaḥ parameśvareṇa na eva āśriteṣu mahatām guṇa doṣa cintā
translated: is still held on his head by the supreme lord; the great ones do not consider the faults of those who have taken refuge with them.

original: śuklīkaroti malināni digantarāṇi candro na śuklayati cātmagataṃ kalaṅkam /
analyzed: śuklīkaroti malināni digantarāṇi candraḥ na śuklayati ca ātma gatam kalaṅkam
translated: The moon whitens the ends of the quarters that are soiled, but does not whiten the blemish that is in itself.

original: nityaṃ yathārthaghaṭanāhitamānasānāṃ svārthodyamo bhavati no mahatāṃ kadācit // / //
analyzed: nityam yathārtha ghaṭana āhita mānasānām sva artha udyamaḥ bhavati no mahatām kadācid
translated: The great ones never strive for their own interests, their minds always fixed on accomplishing the aims of others.

original: gṛhṇāti yuktam itarac ca jahāti dhīmān eṣa svabhāvajanito mahatāṃ vivekaḥ /
analyzed: gṛhṇāti yuktam itarat ca jahāti dhīmān eṣa svabhāva janitaḥ mahatām vivekaḥ
translated: The wise one accepts what is proper and abandons the rest - this is the natural discrimination of the great.

original: anyonyamiśritam api vyatiricya śuddhaṃ dugdhaṃ pibaty udakam ujjhati rājahaṃsaḥ // / //
analyzed: anyonya miśritam api vyatiricya śuddham dugdham pibati udakam ujjhati rājahaṃsaḥ
translated: The royal swan drinks the pure milk mixed with water, leaving the water behind.

original: prāyo bhavaty anucitasthitideśabhājaḥ śreyaḥ svajīvaparipālanamātram eva /
analyzed: prāyas bhavati anucita sthiti deśa bhājaḥ śreyaḥ sva jīva paripālana mātram eva
translated: For those who are in an improper place, it is often best to simply protect one's own life.

original: antaḥprataptamarusaikatadahyamāna mūlasya campakataroḥ ka vikāśacintā // / //
analyzed: antar pratapta maru saikata dahyamāna mūlasya campaka taroḥ ka vikāśa cintā
translated: What thought of blossoming is there for the campaka tree whose roots are being burned by the hot sand in the desert?

original: vidyāyāḥ
analyzed: vidyāyāḥ
translated: Of learning

original: grahaparikavalitatanur api ravir iha bodhayati padmaṣaṇḍāni /
analyzed: graha parikavalita tanuḥ api raviḥ iha bodhayati padma ṣaṇḍāni
translated: Even the sun, whose body is swallowed by Rahu, illuminates the clusters of lotuses here.

original: bhavati vipady api mahatām aṅgīkṛtavastunirvāhaḥ // / //
analyzed: bhavati vipadi api mahatām aṅgīkṛta vastu nirvāhaḥ
translated: Even in adversity, the great ones fulfill the task they have undertaken.

original: praṇatyā bahulābho 'pi na sukhāya manīṣiṇaḥ /
analyzed: praṇatyā na sukhāya manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: Even great gain through flattery does not bring happiness to the wise.

original: cātakaḥ svalpam apy ambu gṛhṇāty anantakandharaḥ // / //
analyzed: cātakaḥ su alpam api ambu gṛhṇāti ananta kandharaḥ
translated: The cātaka bird drinks even a little water, with its endless neck.

original: kasyopayogamātreṇa dhanena ramate manaḥ /
analyzed: kasya upayoga mātreṇa dhanena ramate manaḥ
translated: Whose mind delights in wealth merely for its usefulness?

original: padapramāṇam ādhāram ārūḍhaḥ ko na kampate // / //
analyzed: pada pramāṇam ādhāram ārūḍhaḥ kaḥ na kampate
translated: Who does not tremble when standing on a foundation the size of a foot?

original: upaiti kṣārābdhiṃ sahati bahuvātavyatikaraṃ puro nānābhaṅgān anubhavati paśyaiṣa jaladaḥ /
analyzed: upaiti kṣāra abdhim sahati bahu vāta vyatikaram puras nānā bhaṅgān anubhavati paśya eṣa jaladaḥ
translated: Look, the cloud approaches the salt sea, endures the buffeting of many winds, and experiences various breaks [in its course].

original: kathaṃcil labdhāni pravitarati toyāni jagate guṇaṃ vā doṣaṃ vā gaṇayati na dānavyasanitā // / //
analyzed: kathaṃcid labdhāni pravitarati toyāni jagate guṇam vā doṣam vā gaṇayati na dāna vyasani tā
translated: Somehow obtaining [water], it distributes it to the world. The addiction to giving does not reckon whether the quality is good or bad.

original: vallaṇasyaite
analyzed: vallaṇasya ete
translated: These are of Vallana.

original: sudhādhāmnaḥ kāntiṃ glapayati vilumpaty uḍugaṇaṃ kiraty uṣṇaṃ tejaḥ kumudavanalakṣmīḥ śamayati /
analyzed: sudhā dhāmnaḥ kāntim glapayati vilumpati uḍu gaṇam kirati uṣṇam tejaḥ kumuda vana lakṣmīḥ śamayati
translated: It eclipses the moon's beauty, plunders the host of stars, scatters hot rays, and destroys the beauty of the night-blooming lilies.

original: ravir jānāty eva pratidivasam astādripatanaṃ tathāpi pratyagrābhyudayataralaḥ kiṃ na kurute // / //
analyzed: raviḥ jānāti eva pratidivasam asta adri patanam tathā api pratyagra abhyudaya taralaḥ kim na kurute  /
translated: The sun knows well its fall on the western mountain every day, yet why does it not act with fresh eagerness at dawn?

original: kavirājasya
analyzed: kavirājasya
translated: These are of Kavirāja.

original: Colo ity arthāntaranyāsavrajyā//
analyzed: iti artha antara nyāsa vrajyā
translated: Thus ends the series of Arthāntaranyāsa.

original: tataś cāṭuvrajyā//🔽deva tvadvijayaprayāṇasamaye kāmbojavāhāvalī viṅkhollekhavisarpiṇi kṣitirajaḥpūre viyac cumbati /
analyzed: tatas cāṭu vrajyā  deva tvad vijaya prayāṇa samaye kāmboja vāha āvalī viṅkha ullekha visarpiṇi kṣiti rajaḥpūre viyat cumbati
translated: Then begins the series of Cāṭu.🔽O God, at the time of your victorious expedition, the dust of the earth, spreading like a streak of saffron, kisses the sky.

original: bhānor vājibhir aṅgarūṣaṇarasāsvādaḥ samāsādito labdhaḥ kiṃ ca nabhastalāmaradhunīpaṅkeruhair anvayaḥ // / //
analyzed: bhānoḥ vājibhiḥ aṅgarūṣaṇa rasa āsvādaḥ samāsāditaḥ labdhaḥ kim ca nabhastala amara dhunī paṅkeruhaiḥ anvayaḥ  /
translated: The horses of the sun have attained the taste of rubbing their bodies, and moreover, they have obtained companionship with the lotuses of the heavenly Ganges.

original: tvadyantrāṇāṃ prayāṇeṣv anavaratavalatkarṇatālaprakīrṇair ākīrṇe vyomni sarpasamadagajaghaṭākumbhasindūrapūraiḥ /🔽bibhrāṇāḥ pāribhadradrumakusumaruco raśmayaḥ patyur ahnāṃ madhyāhne 'py astasaṃdhyābhramacakitadṛśaś cakrire cakravākān // /
analyzed: tvad yantrāṇām prayāṇeṣu anavarata valat karṇa tāla prakīrṇaiḥ ākīrṇe vyomni sarpa samada gaja ghaṭā kumbha sindūra pūraiḥ  bibhrāṇāḥ pāribhadra druma kusuma rucaḥ raśmayaḥ patyuḥ ahnām madhyāhne pi asta saṃdhyā bhrama cakita dṛśaḥ cakrire cakravākān  /
translated: In your expeditions, the sky was filled with the red dust from the temples of rutting elephants, scattered by the constantly flapping ears of your horses.🔽The rays of the sun, shining with the color of the flowers of the Paribhadhra tree, made the ruddy geese mistake the midday for the evening twilight.

original: sphīto dhāmnā samaravijayī śrīkaṭākṣapradīrghaḥ snigdhaśyāmaḥ kuvalayarucir yuddhamalla tvadīyaḥ /
analyzed: sphītaḥ dhāmnā samara vijayī śrī kaṭākṣa pradīrghaḥ snigdha śyāmaḥ kuvalaya ruciḥ yuddha malla tvadīyaḥ
translated: Your sword, victorious in battle, is broad like the sidelong glance of Lakshmi, dark and glossy, with the luster of a blue lotus.

original: varṣe 'muṣmin pratinṛpayaśaḥpūragaure parīkṣā kṣīranyastaṃ tulayati mahānīlaratnaṃ kṛpāṇaḥ // / //
analyzed: varṣe muṣmin prati nṛpa yaśaḥ pūra gaure parīkṣā kṣīra nyastam tulayati mahā nīla ratnam kṛpāṇaḥ  /
translated: In this year, it tests the sapphire gem, placed in milk, in the fair complexioned fame of rival kings.

original: digdantinaḥ svakarapuṣkaralekhanībhir gaṇḍasthalān madamasiṃ muhur ādadānāḥ /
analyzed: digdantinaḥ sva kara puṣkara lekhanībhiḥ gaṇḍa sthalāt mada masim muhur ādadānāḥ
translated: The elephants of the directions, repeatedly taking up the ichor-sword from their temples with the brushes of their trunks,

original: śrīcandradeva tava toyanidhitīratāḍīpatrodareṣu vijayastutim ālikhanti // / //
analyzed: śrī candradeva tava toyanidhi tīra tāḍī patra udareṣu vijaya stutim ālikhanti
translated: O Chandradeva, they write the praise of your victory on the surface of palm leaves on the shore of the ocean.

original: abhinandasya
analyzed: abhinandasya
translated: Of Abhinanda

original: satsu rakto dviṣāṃ kālaḥ pītaḥ strīṇāṃ vilocanaiḥ /
analyzed: satsu raktaḥ dviṣām kālaḥ pītaḥ strīṇām vilocanaiḥ
translated: The god of love is red with passion for the good, is drunk with the eyes of women, and is black with the glances of enemies.

original: śubhrakīrtyāsi tat satyaṃ caturvarṇāśramo bhavān // / //
analyzed: śubhra kīrtyā asi tat satyam catur varṇa āśramaḥ bhavān
translated: You are the four varnas and ashramas, that is true.

original: acalasya
analyzed: acalasya
translated: Of Acalas

original: na janayasi kaṃsaharṣaṃ vahasi śarīraṃ yaśodayā juṣṭam /
analyzed: na janayasi kaṃsa harṣam vahasi śarīram yaśodayā juṣṭam
translated: You do not give rise to joy in Kamsa, you bear a body cherished by Yashoda,

original: tyajasi na satyonmukhatām iti satyaṃ vāsudevo 'si // / //
analyzed: tyajasi na satya unmukha tām iti satyam
translated: You do not abandon your devotion to truth, therefore it is true that you are Vasudeva.

original: bhadrasya
analyzed: bhadrasya
translated: Of Bhadra

original: na lopo varṇānāṃ na khalu parataḥ pratyayavidhir vikāro nāsty eva kvacid api na bhagnāḥ prakṛtayaḥ /
analyzed: na lopaḥ varṇānām na khalu paratas pratyaya vidhiḥ vikāraḥ na asti eva kvacid api na bhagnāḥ prakṛtayaḥ
translated: There is no elision of letters, no rule of verbal derivation from the root, no modification anywhere, and the original forms are never broken.

original: guṇo vā vṛddhir vā satatam upakārāya jagatāṃ muner dākṣīputrād api tava samarthaḥ padavidhiḥ // / //
analyzed: guṇaḥ vā vṛddhiḥ vā satatam upakārāya jagatām muneḥ dākṣī putrāt api tava samarthaḥ pada vidhiḥ  /
translated: Or the rule of words for your benefit is always capable of helping the world, even from the son of Daksha's daughter.

original: pāṇineḥ
analyzed: pāṇineḥ
translated: Of Panini

original: satyaṃ tvadguṇakīrtanena sukhayaty ākhaṇḍalaṃ nāradaḥ kiṃ tu śrotrakaṭu kvaṇanti madhupās tatpārijātasrajām /
analyzed: satyam tvad guṇa kīrtanena sukhayati ākhaṇḍalam nāradaḥ kim tu śrotra kaṭu kvaṇanti madhupāḥ tat pārijāta srajām
translated: Truly, Narada delights Indra with the praise of your virtues, but the bees buzzing in the Parijata garland are harsh to the ears.

original: vāryante yadi cāpsaraḥpariṣadā te cāmarāḍambarair udvelladbhujavallikaṅkaṇajhaṇatkāras tadā duḥsahaḥ // / //
analyzed: vāryante yadi ca apsaraḥ pariṣadā te cāmara āḍambaraiḥ udvellat bhuja valli kaṅkaṇa jhaṇatkāraḥ tadā duḥsahaḥ  /
translated: If they are restrained by the group of celestial nymphs with the waving of yak-tail fans, then the jingling of the bracelets on your twining arm-creepers is unbearable.

original: madhukūṭasya
analyzed: madhukūṭasya
translated: Of Madhukuta

original: yasya dvīpaṃ dharitrī sa ca jaladhir abhūd yasya gaṇḍūṣatoyaṃ tasyāścaryaikamūrter api nabhasi vapur yatra durlakṣam āsīt /
analyzed: yasya dvīpam dharitrī sa ca jaladhiḥ abhūt yasya gaṇḍūṣa toyam tasya āścarya eka mūrteḥ api nabhasi vapuḥ yatra durlakṣam āsīt
translated: Whose island was the earth and whose mouthful was the ocean, of him whose form was a wonder unto itself, whose body was difficult to be seen in the sky,

original: tat pītaṃ tvadyaśobhis tribhuvanam abhajaṃs tāni viśrāmahetos tac cāntaḥ kaiṭabhāreḥ sa ca tava hṛdaye vandanīyas tvam ekaḥ // /
analyzed: tat pītam tvad yaśobhiḥ tribhuvanam abhajan tāni viśrāma hetoḥ tat ca antar kaiṭabhāreḥ sa ca tava hṛdaye vandanīyaḥ tvam ekaḥ  /
translated: That has been drunk by your fame, the three worlds have become for resting, and that within the enemy of Kaitabha, and he in your heart, you alone are to be worshipped.

original: tathāgatadāsasya
analyzed: tathāgata dāsasya
translated: Of Tathāgata Dāsa

original: karpāsāsthipracayanicitā nirdhanaśrotriyāṇāṃ yeṣāṃ vātyāpravitatakuṭīprāṅgaṇāntā babhūvuḥ /
analyzed: karpāsa asthi pracaya nicitāḥ nirdhana śrotriyāṇām yeṣām vātyā pravitata kuṭī prāṅgaṇa antāḥ babhūvuḥ
translated: Those of the poor Brāhmaṇas, who were heaped up with cotton seeds, whose courtyards were extended by the wind,

original: tatsaudhānāṃ parisarabhuvi tvatprasādād idānīṃ krīḍāyuddhacchidurayuvatīhāramuktāḥ patanti // / //
analyzed: tad saudhānām parisara bhuvi tvad prasādāt idānīm krīḍā yuddha chidura yuvatī hāra muktāḥ patanti
translated: On the ground around those mansions, now by your grace, the pearls from the necklaces of young women playing in the battle of love fall.

original: śubhāṅgasya🔽lakṣmīvaśīkaraṇacūrṇasahodarāṇi tvatpādapaṅkajarajāṃsi ciraṃ jayanti /
analyzed: śubha aṅgasya  lakṣmī vaśīkaraṇa cūrṇa sahodarāṇi tvad pāda paṅkaja rajāṃsi ciram jayanti
translated: Of Śubhāṅga🔽The dust of your lotus feet, which are the elder sisters of the powder for captivating Lakṣmī, are victorious for a long time.

original: yāni praṇāmamilitāni nṛṇāṃ lalāṭe lumpanti daivalikhitāni durakṣarāṇi // / //
analyzed: yāni praṇāma militāni nṛṇām lalāṭe lumpanti daiva likhitāni durakṣarāṇi
translated: Which, when joined with the forehead of men in salutation, remove the ill-written letters written by fate.

original: abhinandasya
analyzed: abhinandasya
translated: Of Abhinanda

original: tvaṃ cen nātha kalānidhiḥ śaśadharas tat toyanāthā vayaṃ maryādānidhir ambhasāṃ patir atha tvaṃ ced vayaṃ vāridāḥ /
analyzed: tvam ced nātha kalā nidhiḥ śaśadharaḥ tat toya nāthāḥ vayam maryādā nidhiḥ ambhasām patiḥ atha tvam ced vayam vāridāḥ
translated: If you are the moon, the abode of digits, then we are the oceans; if you are the ocean, the abode of the boundary of waters, then we are the clouds.

original: sarvāśāparipūrako jaladharas tvaṃ ced vayaṃ bhūruhaḥ sanmārgvasthitisundaras tvam iha cec chākhī vayaṃ cādhvagāḥ // / //
analyzed: sarva āśā paripūrakaḥ jaladharaḥ tvam ced vayam bhūruhaḥ sat mārgu asthiti sundaraḥ tvam iha ced śākhī vayam ca adhvagāḥ  /
translated: If you are the cloud, the fulfiller of all desires, then we are the trees; if you are the beautiful one abiding in the right path, then we are the travelers.

original: padahīnān bilavasatīn bhujagān iva jātabhogasaṃkocān /
analyzed: pada hīnān bila vasatīn bhujagān iva jāta bhoga saṃkocān
translated: Those who are devoid of feet, like snakes dwelling in holes, with their coils contracted,

original: vyathayati mantrākṣaram iva nāma tavārīn vanecarair gītam // / //
analyzed: vyathayati mantra akṣaram iva nāma tava arīn vanecaraiḥ gītam  /
translated: Your name, like the syllables of a mantra, causes pain, sung by the forest-dwellers.

original: yeṣāṃ veśmasu kambukarparacalattarkudhvanir duḥśravaḥ prāg āsīn naranātha samprati punas teṣāṃ tavānugrahāt /
analyzed: yeṣām veśmasu kambu karpara calat tarku dhvaniḥ duḥśravaḥ prāk āsīt nara nātha samprati punar teṣām tava anugrahāt
translated: In whose houses, O lord of men, the sound of the moving anklets on the hips was difficult to hear before, but now, by your grace,

original: ṣaḍjādikramaraṅgadaṅgulicalatpāṇiskhalatkaṅkaṇa śreṇīnisvanamāṃsalaḥ kalagirāṃ vīṇāravaḥ śrūyate // / //
analyzed: ṣaḍja ādi krama raṅgat aṅguli calat pāṇi skhalat kaṅkaṇa śreṇī nisvana māṃsalaḥ kala girām vīṇā ravaḥ śrūyate  /
translated: The sound of the veena of the sweet-voiced ones is heard, with the rows of bracelets slipping from the hands moving with the fingers in the sequence of Ṣaḍja and others.

original: nātha tvām anuyāce prasīda vijahīhi saṅgarārambham /
analyzed: nātha tvām anuyāce prasīda vijahīhi saṅgara ārambham
translated: O lord, I beseech you, be gracious and give up the preparations for battle.

original: unnatibhājaḥ samprati santi vipakṣāḥ paraṃ girayaḥ // / //
analyzed: unnati bhājaḥ samprati santi vipakṣāḥ param girayaḥ
translated: The mountains, which are proud of their height, are now the enemies.

original: deva svastutir astu nāma hṛdi naḥ sarve vasanty āgamās tīrthaṃ na kvacid īdṛg atrabhavatī tvatkhaḍgadhārā yathā /
analyzed: deva sva stutiḥ astu nāma hṛdi naḥ sarve vasanti āgamāḥ tīrtham na kvacid īdṛś atrabhavatī tvad khaḍga dhārā yathā
translated: O God, let all the scriptures dwell in our hearts, but no sacred place is like the edge of your sword.

original: yām ekaḥ svaśarīraśuddhirasiko mūrdhi pratīcchan ripur dvaividhyād anu pañcatāṃ tadanu ca traidaśyam āpa kṣaṇāt // / //
analyzed: yām ekaḥ sva śarīra śuddhi rasikaḥ mūrdhi pratīcchan ripuḥ dvaividhyāt anu pañcatām tadanu ca traidaśyam āpa kṣaṇāt
translated: The enemy, who was solely devoted to purifying his own body, accepted it on his head, and in a moment, due to its twofold nature, he attained death and then the state of a ghost.

original: rathāṅgasya
analyzed: rathāṅgasya
translated: Of Ratnāṅga

original: matparyantavasuṃdharāvijayine muktādi ratnaṃ mayā sarvaṃ ḍhaukitam eva tubhyam adhunā jāto 'smi niṣkiṃcanaḥ /
analyzed: mad paryanta vasuṃdharā vijayine muktā ādi ratnam mayā sarvam ḍhaukitam eva tubhyam adhunā jātaḥ smi niṣkiṃcanaḥ
translated: I have offered you all the pearls and gems up to my limit of the conquered earth, now I am born as a poor man.

original: ity ullāsitavīcibāhur udayanmārtaṇḍabimbacchalāt prātas taptakuṭhāram eṣa vahate deva tvadagre 'mbudhiḥ // / //
analyzed: iti ullāsita vīci bāhuḥ udayat mārtaṇḍa bimba chalāt prātar tapta kuṭhāram eṣa vahate deva tvad agre mbudhiḥ
translated: Thus, the ocean, with its waves raised like arms, rising from the orb of the rising sun, in the morning, bears the heated axe in front of you, O God.

original: vasukalpasya🔽saṃdiṣṭaṃ marubhūmibhūruhacayair bhūpāla bhūyād bhavān nirjetā navakhaṇḍamaṇḍalabhuvo ye tvatprasādād vayam /
analyzed: vasukalpasya  saṃdiṣṭam maru bhūmi bhūruha cayaiḥ bhūpāla bhūyāt bhavān nirjetā nava khaṇḍa maṇḍala bhuvaḥ ye tvad prasādāt vayam
translated: Of Vasukalpa🔽O King, may you be praised by the rows of trees in the desert land, you who are the conqueror of the earth consisting of the nine divisions, by whose grace we are.

original: pratyāsannavipannavāraḍavadhūnetrapraṇālīgalad bāṣpāmbhaḥplavapaṅkapicchalatalāḥ śrīmuñja modāmahe // / //
analyzed: pratyāsanna vipanna vāraḍa vadhū netra praṇālī galat bāṣpa ambhaḥ plava paṅka picchala talāḥ śrī muñja modāmahe  /
translated: We rejoice, O glorious Muñja, on the ground slippery with the mud of the water flowing from the eyes of the wives of the nearby dead elephants.

original: tanvīm ujjhitabhūṣaṇāṃ kalagiraṃ sītkāram ātanvatīṃ vepantīṃ vraṇitādharāṃ vivasanāṃ romodgamaṃ bibhratīm /🔽hemante himaśītamārutabhayād āśliṣya dorbhyāṃ tanuṃ svāṃ mūrtiṃ dayitām ivātirasikāṃ tvadvidviṣaḥ śerate // / //
analyzed: tanvīm ujjhita bhūṣaṇām kala giram sītkāram ātanvatīm vepantīm vraṇita adharām vivasanām roma udgamam bibhratīm  hemante hima śīta māruta bhayāt āśliṣya dorbhyām tanum svām mūrtim dayitām iva ati rasikām tvad vidviṣaḥ śerate  /
translated: Thin, devoid of ornaments, uttering cries of pain, trembling, with wounded lips, naked, and horripilated.🔽In winter, they lie down, embracing their own bodies with their two arms, out of fear of the cold wind and snow, like their own beloved forms, extremely passionate, your enemies lie down.

original: bhūsamparkarajonipātamalināḥ svasmād gṛhāt pracyutāḥ sāmānyair api jantubhiḥ karatalair niḥśaṅkam āliṅgitāḥ /
analyzed: bhū samparka rajaḥ nipāta malināḥ svasmāt gṛhāt pracyutāḥ sāmānyaiḥ api jantubhiḥ kara talaiḥ niḥśaṅkam āliṅgitāḥ
translated: Dirty from the dust of contact with the ground, expelled from their own homes, fearlessly embraced by the palms of even ordinary creatures,

original: nirlagnāḥ kvacid ekatām upagatā baddhāḥ kvacin mocitā akṣāṇām iva śārayaḥ pratigṛhaṃ bhrāntās tavāristriyaḥ // / //🔽varṣāsambhṛtapītisāram avaśaṃ stabdhāṅghrihastadvayaṃ bhekaṃ mūrdhni nigṛhya kajjalarajaḥśyāmaṃ bhujaṅgaṃ sthitam /
analyzed: nirlagnāḥ kvacid eka tām upagatāḥ baddhāḥ kvacid mocitāḥ akṣāṇām iva śārayaḥ pratigṛham bhrāntāḥ tava ari striyaḥ       varṣā sambhṛta pīti sāram avaśam stabdha aṅghri hasta dvayam bhekam mūrdhni nigṛhya kajjala rajaḥ śyāmam bhujaṅgam sthitam
translated: Unattached, sometimes united, sometimes bound and released, like the eyes of fish, your enemy's wives wander from house to house.

original: mugdhā vyādhavadhus tavārinagare śūnye cirāt samprati svaṛnopaskṛtimuṣṭisāyakadhiyā sākūtam āditsati // / //
analyzed: mugdhā vyādha vadhuḥ tava ari nagare śūnye cirāt samprati sva ṛna upaskṛti muṣṭi sāyaka dhiyā sa ākūtam āditsati  /
translated: The foolish wife of a hunter, in your enemy's city, after a long time, now sees a frog, swollen with the monsoon rains, its two legs and hands stiff, holding a snake on its head, dark like collyrium dust, and stands still.🔽With the idea that it is a gift from her husband, she eagerly desires to seize it.

original: paryaṅkaḥ śithilīkṛto na bhavatā siṃhāsanān notthitaṃ na krodhānaladhūmarājir iva ca bhrūvallir ullāsitā /
analyzed: paryaṅkaḥ śithilīkṛtaḥ na bhavatā siṃhāsanāt nā utthitam na krodha anala dhūma rājiḥ iva ca bhrū valliḥ ullāsitā
translated: You have not loosened your cross-legged posture, nor have you risen from your lion throne, nor have you knitted your eyebrows like a line of smoke from the fire of anger.

original: rājñāṃ tvaccaraṇāravindam atha ca śrīcandra puṣpanty amūś cañcaccārumarīcisaṃcayamucāṃ cūḍāmaṇīnāṃ rucaḥ // / //
analyzed: rājñām tvad caraṇa aravindam atha ca śrī candra amūḥ cañcat cāru marīci saṃcaya mucām cūḍāmaṇīnām rucaḥ  /
translated: But, O King Candra, the rays of those crest jewels, which are scattered with a mass of beautiful light, bloom at your lotus feet.

original: suvinītasya
analyzed: su vinītasya
translated: Of Suvinīta

original: dvāraṃ khaḍgibhir āvṛtaṃ bahir api praklinnagaṇḍair gajair antaḥ kañcukibhiḥ sphuranmaṇidharair adhyāsitā bhūmayaḥ /
analyzed: dvāram khaḍgibhiḥ āvṛtam bahis api praklinna gaṇḍaiḥ gajaiḥ antar kañcukibhiḥ sphurat maṇidharaiḥ adhyāsitāḥ bhūmayaḥ
translated: The door is guarded by sword-bearers, outside, and the floors are occupied by intoxicated elephants with swollen cheeks, inside, by chamberlains wearing sparkling jewels.

original: ākrāntaṃ mahiṣībhir eva śayanaṃ tvadvidviṣāṃ mandire rājan saiva cirantanapraṇayinīśūnye 'pi rājyasthitiḥ // / //
analyzed: ākrāntam mahiṣībhiḥ eva śayanam tvad vidviṣām mandire rājan sā eva cirantana praṇayinī śūnye rājya sthitiḥ
translated: The bed in the palace of your enemies is occupied only by their queens. O King, even in that empty palace, your long-standing affection for the kingdom remains.

original: vijayapālasya
analyzed: vijayapālasya
translated: Of Vijayapāla

original: atyuktau yadi na prakupyasi mṛṣāvādaṃ na cen manyase tad brūmo 'dbhutakīrtaneṣu rasanā keṣāṃ na kaṇḍūyate /
analyzed: atyuktau yadi na prakupyasi mṛṣāvādam na ced manyase tat brūmaḥ dbhuta kīrtaneṣu rasanā keṣām na kaṇḍūyate
translated: If you do not get angry at hyperbole, if you do not think it is false speech, then we say, in the praises of the marvelous, whose tongue does not itch?

original: deva tvadvijayapratāpadahanajvālāvalīśoṣitāḥ sarve vāridhayas tato ripuvadhūbāṣpāmbubhiḥ pūritāḥ // / //
analyzed: deva tvad vijaya pratāpa dahana jvālā āvalī śoṣitāḥ sarve vāridhayaḥ tatas ripu vadhū bāṣpa ambubhiḥ pūritāḥ  /
translated: O God, all the oceans have been dried up by the flames of the fire of your victorious valor, and then they are filled with the tears of the wives of your enemies.

original: tāḍītāḍaṅkamātrābharaṇapariṇatīny ullasatsinduvāra sragdāmāni dviṣāṃ vo ghanajaghanajaradbhūribhūrjāṃśukāni /
analyzed: tāḍīta āḍaṅka mātra ābharaṇa pariṇatīni ullasat sinduvāra sraj dāmāni dviṣām vaḥ ghana jaghana jarat bhūri bhūrja aṃśukāni
translated: The ornaments of the enemies are reduced to mere bracelets and anklets, the garlands and wreaths are of sindhuvara flowers, and the garments are of many bhūrja leaves worn out by the heavy hips.🔽On the slopes of the Vindhya mountain, the inner apartments, with the tips of the breasts painted with minerals, and with the young monkeys clinging to their laps, are constantly sporting.🔽And from the river, which was almost stopped by the weight of the elephants that followed you, and from which the saliva trickled down from the coils of the snakes that were tired inside,

original: vindhyaskandheṣu dhātudravaracitakucaprāntapatrāṅkurāṇi krīḍanti kroḍalagnaiḥ kapiśiśubhir aviśrāntam antaḥpurāṇi // / //🔽tvannāsīravisārivāraṇabharabhraśyanmahīyantraṇād antaḥkhinnabhujaṅgabhogavigalallālābhir āsīn nadī /
analyzed: vindhya skandheṣu dhātu drava racita kuca prānta patra aṅkurāṇi krīḍanti kroḍa lagnaiḥ kapi śiśubhiḥ aviśrāntam antaḥpurāṇi  / tvad nāsīra visāri vāraṇa bhara bhraśyat mahī yantraṇāt antar khinna bhujaṅga bhoga vigalat lālābhiḥ āsīt nadī
translated: And in this river, the birth of the lotuses was made by the rows of hoods of the female elephants, eager for water sports, which had the luster of jewels.🔽Of Gangadhara🔽When you, having gone to the battlefield, placed the bow on the string, O god, listen to what was attained by which power.🔽By the bow, the arrows; by the arrows, the enemy's head; by that, the earth; by that, you; by you, fame; by fame, the three worlds.🔽Of the battlefield🔽 And the king said, O messenger, go to the king of the Magadhas and tell him this: You have done well in giving your daughter to the king of the Kurus.🔽 Translation: The ornaments of the enemies are reduced to mere bracelets and anklets, the garlands and wreaths are of sindhuvara flowers, and the garments are of many bhūrja leaves worn out by the heavy hips.🔽On the slopes of the Vindhya mountain, the inner apartments, with the tips of the breasts painted with minerals, and with the young monkeys clinging to their laps, are constantly sporting.🔽And from the river, which was almost stopped by the weight of the elephants that followed you, and from which the saliva trickled down from the coils of the snakes that were tired inside,

original: kiṃ cāsyāṃ jalakelilālasavalannāgāṅganānāṃ phaṇa śreṇībhir maṇikeśarābhir abhavat sambhūtir ambhoruhām // / //
analyzed: kim ca asyām jala keli lālasa valat nāga aṅganānām phaṇa śreṇībhiḥ maṇi kesarābhiḥ abhavat sambhūtiḥ ambhoruhām  /
translated: And in this river, the birth of the lotuses was made by the rows of hoods of the female elephants, eager for water sports, which had the luster of jewels.

original: gaṅgādharasya
analyzed: gaṅgādharasya
translated: Of Gangadhara

original: saṃgrāmāṅgaṇasaṃgatena bhavatā cāpe samāropite devākarṇaya yena yena mahasā yad yat samāsāditam /
analyzed: saṃgrāma aṅgaṇa saṃgatena bhavatā cāpe samāropite deva ākarṇaya yena yena mahasā yat yat samāsāditam
translated: When you, having gone to the battlefield, placed the bow on the string, O god, listen to what was attained by which power.

original: kodaṇḍena śarāḥ śaraī ripuśiras tenāpi bhūmaṇḍalaṃ tena tvaṃ bhavatā ca kīrtir anaghā kīrtyā ca lokatrayam // / //🔽saṃgrāmāṅgaṇasya
analyzed: kodaṇḍena śarāḥ ripu śiraḥ tena api bhū maṇḍalam tena tvam bhavatā ca kīrtiḥ anaghā kīrtyā ca lokatrayam      🔽saṃgrāma aṅgaṇasya
translated: By the bow, the arrows; by the arrows, the enemy's head; by that, the earth; by that, you; by you, fame; by fame, the three worlds.

original: śarair vyarthaṃ nātha tribhuvanajayārambhacaturais tava jyānirghoṣaṃ nṛpatir iha ko nāma sahate /
analyzed: śaraiḥ vyartham nātha tribhuvana jaya ārambha caturaiḥ tava jyā nirghoṣam nṛpatiḥ iha kaḥ nāma sahate
translated: O Lord, which king here can bear the twang of your bowstring, skilled in the commencement of victory for the three worlds, in vain with arrows?

original: yam uccair ākarṇya tridaśapatir apy āhavabhiyā hriyā pārśvaṃ paśyan nibhṛtanibhṛtaṃ muñcati dhanuḥ // / //
analyzed: yam uccais ākarṇya tridaśa patiḥ api āhava bhiyā hriyā pārśvam paśyan nibhṛta nibhṛtam muñcati dhanuḥ  /
translated: Hearing it loudly, even the Lord of the Gods, out of fear of battle, out of shame, looking sideways, releases his bow very carefully, very carefully.

original: nāhillasya
analyzed: nāhillasya
translated: Of Nāhillas

original: ṛkṣasya kroḍasaṃdhiprahitamukhatayā maṇḍalībhūtamūrter ārāt suptasya vīra tvadarivarapuradvāri nīhārakāle /
analyzed: ṛkṣasya kroḍa saṃdhi prahita mukha tayā maṇḍalībhūta mūrteḥ ārāt suptasya vīra tvad ari vara pura dvāri nīhāra kāle
translated: O Hero, near the gate of the excellent city of your enemy, in the dew season, of the bear, with its body bent in a circle by thrusting its face between its forearms, sleeping at a distance,

original: prātar nidrāvinodakramajanitamukhonmīlitaṃ cakṣur ekaṃ vyādhāḥ pālālabhasmasthitadahanakaṇākāram ālokayanti // / //
analyzed: prātar nidrā vinoda krama janita mukha unmīlitam cakṣuḥ ekam vyādhāḥ pālāla bhasma sthita dahana kaṇā ākāram ālokayanti  /
translated: The hunters in the morning, when it wakes up from sleep, look at its one eye opened wide, resembling a spark of fire in the ashes of chaff.

original: te kaupīnadhanās ta eva hi paraṃ dhātrīphalaṃ bhuñjate teṣāṃ dvāri nadanti vājinivahās tair eva labdhā kṣitiḥ /
analyzed: te kaupīna dhanāḥ te eva hi param dhātrī phalam bhuñjate teṣām dvāri nadanti vāji nivahāḥ taiḥ eva labdhā kṣitiḥ
translated: They are the ones who have only a loincloth as wealth, they alone eat the fruit of the Dhātrī tree, at their gate the troops of horses neigh, the earth is obtained by them alone.

original: tair etat samalaṃkṛtaṃ nijakulaṃ kiṃ vā bahu brūmahe ye dṛṣṭāḥ parameśvareṇa bhavatā ruṣṭena tuṣṭena vā // / //
analyzed: taiḥ etat samalaṃkṛtam nija kulam kim vā bahu brūmahe ye dṛṣṭāḥ parameśvareṇa bhavatā ruṣṭena tuṣṭena vā
translated: By them this family is adorned, what more shall we say? They who are seen by you, the Supreme Lord, whether angry or pleased.

original: jayādityasya
analyzed: jaya ādityasya
translated: Of Jayāditya

original: dattendrābhayavibhramādbhutabhujāsambhāragambhīrayā tvadvṛttyā śithilīkṛtas tribhuvanatrāṇāya nārāyaṇaḥ /
analyzed: datta indra abhaya vibhrama adbhuta bhujā sambhāra gambhīrayā tvad vṛttyā śithilīkṛtaḥ tribhuvana trāṇāya nārāyaṇaḥ
translated: Narayana, having relaxed his efforts to protect the three worlds due to the awe-inspiring depth of your conduct, which is free from the delusion of granting fearlessness to Indra,

original: antastoṣatuṣārasaurabhamayaśvāsānilāpūraṇa prāṇottuṅgabhujaṅgatalpam adhunā bhadreṇa nidrāyate // / //
analyzed: antar toṣa tuṣāra saurabha maya śvāsa anila āpūraṇa prāṇa uttuṅga bhujaṅga talpam adhunā bhadreṇa nidrāyate  /
translated: Nārāyaṇa, who had relaxed his protection of the three worlds for the sake of granting fearlessness to Indra, now sleeps happily on the lofty bed of the serpent Śeṣa, filled with the breath of his inner contentment, which is cool like the fragrance of jasmine.

original: vatse mādhavi tāta campaka śiśo mākanda kaunti priye hā mātar madayanti hā kurabaka bhrātaḥ svasar mālati /
analyzed: vatse mādhavi tāta campaka śiśo mākanda kaunti priye hā mātar madayanti hā kurabaka bhrātar svasar mālati
translated: O child Mādhava, father Campaka, young one Mākandika, Kounteya's beloved, alas mother Madayantī, alas Karavīra, brother, sister Mālatī,

original: ity evaṃ ripumandireṣu bhavataḥ śṛṇvanti naktaṃcarā golāṅgūlavimardasambhramavaśād udyānadevīgiraḥ // / //
analyzed: iti evam ripu mandireṣu bhavataḥ śṛṇvanti naktaṃcarāḥ go lāṅgūla vimarda sambhrama vaśāt udyāna devī giraḥ
translated: thus the night-wandering spirits hear the words of the garden goddess in the houses of enemies, out of the excitement of the collision with the porcupine.

original: śubhāṅgasya🔽vajrin vajram idaṃ jahīhi bhagavan īśa triśūlena kiṃ viṣṇo tvaṃ ca vimuñca cakram amarāḥ sarve tyajantv āyudham /
analyzed: śubha aṅgasya  vajrin vajram idam jahīhi bhagavan īśa triśūlena kim viṣṇo tvam ca vimuñca cakram amarāḥ sarve tyajantu āyudham
translated: Of Śubhāṅga🔽O Indra, give up this thunderbolt, O Lord, what is the use of the trident? O Viṣṇu, you also release the discus, all the gods should lay down their weapons.

original: adyāyaṃ paracakrabhūmanṛpater voḍhuṃ trilokīdhuraṃ prauḍhārātighaṭāvighaṭṭanapaṭur dordaṇḍa evodyataḥ // / //
analyzed: adyā ayam para cakra bhūma nṛpateḥ voḍhum trilokī dhuram prauḍha arāti ghaṭā vighaṭṭana paṭuḥ dordaṇḍaḥ eva udyataḥ  /
translated: Today, this very arm of yours, which is skilled in destroying the multitude of powerful enemies, is ready to bear the burden of the three worlds of the king of the earth, who is struck down by the enemy's army.

original: bāṇās te paracakravikramakalāvailakṣyadikṣāguror vīkṣante mihirāṃśumāṃsalarucaḥ kṣiptāḥ pratidveṣiṇaḥ /
analyzed: bāṇāḥ te para cakra vikrama kalā vailakṣya dikṣā guroḥ vīkṣante mihira aṃśu māṃsala rucaḥ kṣiptāḥ pratidveṣiṇaḥ
translated: Your arrows, thrown at the enemies, with a splendor intense like the rays of the sun, look at the directions, the teachers of the art of the valor of the enemy's army.

original: hastāhallitahāravallitaralā yuddhāṅgaṇālokana krīḍāloladigaṅganāsamudayonmuktāḥ kaṭākṣā iva // / //
analyzed: hasta āhallita hāra valli taralāḥ yuddha aṅgaṇa ālokana krīḍā lola diś aṅganā samudaya unmuktāḥ kaṭākṣāḥ iva
translated: Your arrows, thrown at the enemies, with a splendor intense like the rays of the sun, seem to be the glances of the assembled young women of the directions, playful and eager to see the battlefield, their pearl necklaces trembling in their excitement.

original: mañjuśrīmitrasya
analyzed: mañjuśrī mitrasya
translated: Of Mañjuśrīmitra

original: mandodvṛntaiḥ śirobhir maṇibharagurubhiḥ prauḍharomāñcadaṇḍa sphāyannirmokasaṃdhiprasaradavigalatsaṃmadasvedapūrāḥ /
analyzed: manda udvṛntaiḥ śirobhiḥ maṇi bhara gurubhiḥ prauḍha romāñca daṇḍa sphāyat nirmoka saṃdhi prasarat avigalat saṃmada sveda pūrāḥ
translated: With their heads slightly bent, heavy with the weight of jewels, with the staff of horripilation erect, with the full flow of sweat of joy oozing from the joints of the expanding skin,

original: jihvāyugmābhipūrṇānandaviṣamasamudgīrṇavarṇābhirāmaṃ velāśailāṅkabhājo bhujagayuvatayas tvadguṇān udgṛṇanti // / //
analyzed: jihvā yugma abhipūrṇa ānanda viṣama samudgīrṇa varṇa abhirāmam velā śaila aṅka bhājaḥ bhujaga yuvatayaḥ tvad guṇān udgṛṇanti  /
translated: The young women of the serpents, their mouths filled with pairs of tongues, joyfully utter the praise of your qualities, which are like the waves of the ocean of the moon.

original: murāreḥ
analyzed: murāreḥ
translated: Of Murāri

original: jīyāsuḥ kalikālakarṇakajagaddāridryadārūdara vyāghūrṇadghuṇacūrṇalaṅgimajuṣas tvatpādayoḥ pāṃsavaḥ /
analyzed: jīyāsuḥ kali kāla karṇaka jagat dāridrya dāru udara vyāghūrṇat ghuṇa cūrṇa laṅgima juṣaḥ tvad pādayoḥ pāṃsavaḥ
translated: Long live the dust of your feet, which is the great belly of the wood for burning the poverty of the world, the ornament of the whirling dust of the chaff,

original: lakṣmīsadmasarojareṇusuhṛdaḥ sevāvanamrībhavad bhūmīpālakirīṭaratnakiraṇajyotsnānadīvālikāḥ // / //
analyzed: lakṣmī sadma saroja reṇu suhṛdaḥ sevā avanamrībhavat bhūmīpāla kirīṭa ratna kiraṇa jyotsnā nadī vālikāḥ  /
translated: The dust of the lotus, the abode of Lakṣmī, the friend of the dust of the lotus, the dust of the crest-jewel of the king, which is the river of the moonlight of the rays,

original: vallaṇasya
analyzed: vallaṇasya
translated: Of Vallaṇa

original: pṛthur asi guṇaiḥ kīrtyā rāmo nalo bharato bhavān mahati samare śatrughnas tvaṃ sadaiva yudhiṣṭhiraḥ /
analyzed: pṛthuḥ asi guṇaiḥ kīrtyā rāmaḥ nalaḥ bharataḥ bhavān mahati samare śatrughnaḥ tvam sadā eva yudhiṣṭhiraḥ
translated: You are a hero, you are a hero of virtues and fame, you are Rama, Nala, Bharata, Shatrughna in a great battle, you are always Yudhishthira in battle.

original: iti sucaritair bibhrad rūpaṃ ciraṃtanabhūbhujāṃ katham asi na māṃdhātā deva trilokavijayy api // / //
analyzed: iti su caritaiḥ bibhrat rūpam ciraṃtana bhūbhujām katham asi na māṃdhātā deva triloka vijayī api
translated: Thus bearing the form of the ancient kings with your good deeds, how are you not Mandhata, O God, even though you have conquered the three worlds?

original: prabhur asi vayaṃ mālākāravratavyavasāyino vacanakusumaṃ tenāsmābhis tavādaraḍhaukitam /
analyzed: prabhuḥ asi vayam mālākāra vrata vyavasāyinaḥ vacana kusumam tena asmābhiḥ tava ādara ḍhaukitam
translated: You are the lord, we are engaged in the vow of garland-makers, therefore we have offered this flower of words to you with respect.

original: yadi tad aguṇaṃ kaṇṭhe mā dhās tathorasi mā kṛthā navam iti kiyat karṇe dhehi kṣaṇaṃ phalatu śramaḥ // / //
analyzed: yadi tat aguṇam kaṇṭhe mā dhāḥ tathā urasi mā kṛthāḥ navam iti kiyat karṇe dhehi kṣaṇam phalatu śramaḥ  /
translated: If that is not good, do not place it on your neck, do not put it on your chest, put it in your ear for a moment, let the effort bear fruit.

original: bhayam ekam anekebhyaḥ śatrubhyo yugapat sadā /
analyzed: bhayam ekam anekebhyaḥ śatrubhyaḥ yugapad sadā
translated: Fear from many enemies simultaneously at all times.

original: dadāti tac ca tenāsti rājaṃś citram idaṃ mahat // / //
analyzed: dadāti tat ca tena asti rājan citram idam mahat
translated: And that is given by him, O king, this is a great wonder.

original: sarvadā sarvado 'sīti mithyā saṃstūyase budhaiḥ /
analyzed: sarvadā sarva do si iti mithyā saṃstūyase budhaiḥ
translated: You are always the giver of everything, thus you are falsely praised by the wise.

original: nārayo lebhire pṛṣṭhaṃ na vakṣaḥ parayoṣitaḥ // / //
analyzed: na arayaḥ lebhire pṛṣṭham na vakṣaḥ para yoṣitaḥ
translated: Enemies did not obtain your back, nor the chest of other women.

original: apūrveyaṃ dhanurvidyā bhavatā śikṣitā kutaḥ /
analyzed: apūrvā iyam dhanuḥ vidyā bhavatā śikṣitā kutas
translated: From where did you learn this unprecedented archery?

original: mārgaṇaughaḥ samāyāti guṇo yāti digantaram // / //
analyzed: mārgaṇa oghaḥ samāyāti guṇaḥ yāti digantaram
translated: The multitude of arrows comes, the string goes to the end of the bow.

original: sālakānanayoge 'pi sālakānanavarjitā /
analyzed: sāla kānana yoge sāla kānana varjitā
translated: Even though adorned with a grove of sāla trees, she is devoid of a grove of sāla trees.

original: hārāvaruddhakaṇṭhāpi vihārārivadhūs tava // / //
analyzed: hāra avaruddha kaṇṭhā api vihāra ari vadhūḥ tava  /
translated: Even though her neck is encircled by a necklace, she is the wife of an enemy of the pleasure grove, yours.

original: amī vīryamitrasya🔽karṣadbhiḥ sicayāñcalān atirasāt kurvadbhir āliṅganam /
analyzed: amī vīrya mitrasya  karṣadbhiḥ sicayā añcalān ati rasāt kurvadbhiḥ āliṅganam
translated: These are of Vīryamitra🔽Pulling at the hems of their garments out of intense passion, making them embrace,

original: gṛhṇānaiḥ kacam ālikhadbhir adharaṃ vidrāvayadbhiḥ kucau /
analyzed: gṛhṇānaiḥ kacam ālikhadbhiḥ adharam vidrāvayadbhiḥ kucau
translated: Grasping their hair, kissing their lips, driving away their breasts,

original: pratyakṣe 'pi kaliṅgamaṇḍalapater antaḥpurāṇām aho dhik kaṣṭaṃ viṭapair viṭair iva vane kiṃ nāma nāceṣṭitam // / //
analyzed: pratyakṣe pi kaliṅga maṇḍala pateḥ antaḥpurāṇām aho dhik kaṣṭam viṭapaiḥ viṭaiḥ iva vane kim nāma na a ceṣṭitam  /
translated: Even in the presence of the king of the Kaliṅga region, alas, what is not done by the young men in the forest, as if by the branches of the trees, to the women of his harem?

original: vasukalpasya
analyzed: vasukalpasya
translated: This is of Vasukalpa

original: gambhīranīrasarasīr api paṅkaśeṣāḥ kurvanti ye dinakarasya karās ta eva /🔽stvadvīravairivanitānayanāmbuleśa śoṣe kathaṃ pratihatā iti me vitarkaḥ // / //
analyzed: gambhīra nīra sarasīḥ api paṅka śeṣāḥ kurvanti ye dinakarasya karāḥ te eva  s tvad vīra vairi vanitā nayana ambu leśa śoṣe katham pratihatāḥ iti me vitarkaḥ
translated: Those very rays of the sun that make even deep water-lakes with remaining mud,🔽How is it that they are obstructed in drying up the mere drop of tears from the eyes of the wives of your enemies, I wonder.

original: tvatsainyaglapitasya pannagapater acchinnadhārākramaṃ visphārāyataśālini pratiphaṇaṃ phelāmbhasi bhraśyati /
analyzed: tvad sainya glapitasya pannaga pateḥ acchinna dhārā kramam visphāra āyata śālini pratiphaṇam phelā ambhasi bhraśyati
translated: In the wide-spreading water-filled hoods of the lord of serpents, which are being cut off in succession by your army, as they fall,

original: deva kṣmāvalayaprabho phaṇikulaiḥ pravyaktam ekottara sthūlastambhasahasradhāritam iva kṣmācakram ālokyate // / //
analyzed: deva kṣmā valaya prabho phaṇi kulaiḥ pravyaktam eka uttara sthūla stambha sahasra dhāritam iva kṣmā cakram ālokyate
translated: O Lord, the earth appears as if it were supported by a thousand huge pillars, one more than a thousand, by the multitude of serpents.

original: śeṣaṃ kleśayituṃ diśaḥ sthagayituṃ peṣṭuṃ dharitrībhṛtaḥ sindhūn dhūlibhareṇa kardamayituṃ tair eva roddhuṃ nabhaḥ /
analyzed: śeṣam kleśayitum diśaḥ sthagayitum peṣṭum dharitrī bhṛtaḥ sindhūn dhūli bhareṇa kardamayitum taiḥ eva roddhum nabhaḥ
translated: To torment the rest, to obstruct the directions, to crush the mountain-kings, to turn the seas into a mass of dust, and to block the sky with them alone,

original: nāsīre ca muhur muhuś cala calety ālāpakolāhalān kartuṃ nātha varūthinīyam avanīṃ jetuṃ punas tvadbhujau // / //
analyzed: nāsīre ca muhur muhur cala cala iti ālāpa kolāhalān kartum nātha varūthinī iyam avanīm jetum punar tvad bhujau
translated: O Lord, to make the earth your battlefield, to repeatedly shout Move, move! and to conquer the earth again with your arms.

original: vasukalpasya🔽deva tvatsainyabhārād avanim avanatāṃ dhartum uttabdhadehaḥ sphūtkārakṣveḍamīlatphaṇaśatanipatatpīnalālāpravāhaḥ /🔽dṛṣṭaḥ prārohaśālī vaṭa iva phalito raktamūrdhanyaratnaḥ kūrmeṇoddhṛtya kaṇṭhaṃ nijavipulavapuś catvare sarparājaḥ // /
analyzed: vasukalpasya  deva tvad sainya bhārāt avanim avanatām dhartum uttabdha dehaḥ sphūtkāra kṣveḍa mīlat phaṇa śata nipatat pīna lālā pravāhaḥ  dṛṣṭaḥ prāroha śālī vaṭaḥ iva phalitaḥ rakta mūrdhani aratnaḥ kūrmeṇa uddhṛtya kaṇṭham nija vipula vapuḥ catvare sarpa rājaḥ  /
translated: Of Vasukalpa🔽O Lord, the king of serpents, having raised his neck and his huge body in the square, is seen like a fruitful banyan tree with a red jewel on its top, with a stream of thick saliva falling from the hundred hissing and expanding hoods, in order to support the earth, which is bent down by the weight of your army.

original: ambhaḥ kardamatām upaiti sahasā paṅkadravaḥ pāṃśutāṃ pāṃśur vāraṇakarṇatālapavanair dikprāntanīhāratām /
analyzed: ambhaḥ kardama tām upaiti sahasā paṅka dravaḥ pāṃśu tām pāṃśuḥ vāraṇakarṇa tāla pavanaiḥ diś prānta nīhāra tām
translated: Water suddenly becomes mud, the liquid mud becomes dust, the dust is turned into snow at the edge of the sky by the wind from the ears of the elephants,

original: nimnatvaṃ girayaḥ samaṃ viṣamatāṃ śūnyaṃ janasthānakaṃ niryāte tvayi rājyapāla bhavati tyaktasvabhāvaṃ jagat // / //
analyzed: nimna tvam girayaḥ samam viṣama tām śūnyam janasthānakam niryāte tvayi rājyapāla bhavati tyakta svabhāvam jagat  /
translated: The mountains become level, the unevenness becomes even, the empty city becomes a place of people, when you leave, O protector of the kingdom. The world abandons its own nature.

original: mahodadheḥ
analyzed: mahā udadheḥ
translated: Of the great ocean

original: asindūreṇa sīmanto mā bhūn no yoṣitām iti /
analyzed: a sindūreṇa sīmantaḥ mā bhūt naḥ yoṣitām iti
translated: So that there may be no parting line on the women's foreheads without vermilion.

original: ataḥ pariharanty ājā vasiṃ dūreṇa te 'rayaḥ // / //
analyzed: atas pariharanti ājā vasim dūreṇa te rayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the cows avoid the border, those enemies are far away.

original: deva tvaṃ kila kuntalagraharuciḥ kāñcīm apāsārayan kṣipraṃ kṣiprakaras tataḥ prahaṇanaṃ prārabdham aṅgeṣv api /
analyzed: deva tvam kila kuntala graha ruciḥ kāñcīm apāsārayan kṣipram kṣipra karaḥ tatas prahaṇanam prārabdham aṅgeṣu api
translated: O god, you are indeed fond of seizing the hair, removing the girdle, and quickly, with quick hands, starting to strike even on the limbs.

original: ity ākūtajuṣas tava stavakṛtā vaitālikenodite lajjante pramadāḥ parasparam abhiprekṣyārayo bibhyati // / //
analyzed: iti ākūta juṣaḥ tava stava kṛtā vaitālikena udite lajjante pramadāḥ parasparam abhiprekṣya arayaḥ bibhyati  /
translated: Thus, when the panegyrist, delighting in your intentions, sings this, the women are ashamed, and the enemies, fearing each other, are afraid.

original: bhīme prasthānabhāji sphuradasijaladāpahnutadveṣivahnau gṛhṇītāhnāya sarve bhuvi bhuvanabhujaś cāmaraṃ vā diśo vā /
analyzed: bhīme prasthāna bhāji sphurat asi jalada apahnuta dveṣi vahnau gṛhṇīta ahnāya sarve bhuvi bhuvana bhujaḥ cāmaram vā diśaḥ vā
translated: When Bhima, who bears the sword and cloud-like enemies, is about to depart, all on earth, the lords of the world, may take the chowrie or the directions for the day.

original: naivaṃ ced vas tadānīṃ pradhanadhṛtadhanur muktarāvarṇaviddhaṃ gṛdhrā mūrdhānam ūrdhvaṃ nabhasi rabhasino lāghavenoddharanti // /
analyzed: na evam ced vaḥ tadānīm pradhana dhṛta dhanuḥ mukta rāvarṇa viddham gṛdhrāḥ mūrdhānam ūrdhvam nabhasi rabhasinaḥ lāghavena uddharanti
translated: If not, then at that time, the vultures, with their sharp beaks, quickly pluck up the head from the sky, pierced by the released arrow of the one holding the bow in the great battle.

original: vasukalpasya
analyzed: vasukalpasya
translated: Of Vasukalpa

original: bhavān īhitakṛn nityaṃ tvaṃ himānīgiristhitaḥ /
analyzed: bhavān īhita kṛt nityam tvam himānī giri sthitaḥ
translated: You are always the fulfiller of desires, as you reside on the snow-peaked mountain.

original: ataḥ śaṃkara evāsi sadā skandaḥ paraṃ na te // / //🔽ābālyādhigamān mayaiva gamitaḥ koṭiṃ parām unnater asmatsaṃkathayaiva pārthivasutaḥ sampraty ayaṃ lajjate /
analyzed: atas śaṃkaraḥ eva asi sadā skandaḥ param na te     ā bālya adhigamāt mayā eva gamitaḥ koṭim parām unnateḥ asmad saṃkathayā eva pārthiva sutaḥ samprati ayam lajjate
translated: Therefore, you are indeed Śaṅkara (Śiva), O Skanda, but not to others.🔽From childhood, I have brought him to the highest peak of prosperity. Now, this prince is ashamed due to our conversation.

original: itthaṃ khinna ivātmajena yaśasā dattāvalambo 'mbudheḥ prāptas tīratapovanāni bhavato vṛddho guṇānāṃ gaṇaḥ // / //
analyzed: ittham khinnaḥ iva ātmajena yaśasā datta avalambaḥ mbudheḥ prāptaḥ tīra tapovanāni bhavataḥ vṛddhaḥ guṇānām gaṇaḥ  /
translated: Thus, as if tired, the old group of your virtues, supported by the fame of your son, has reached the penance groves on the shore of the ocean.

original: stanayugam aśrusnātaṃ samīpataravartihṛdayaśokāgneḥ /
analyzed: stana yugam aśru snātam samīpatara varti hṛdaya śoka agneḥ
translated: The breasts of your enemy's wives, bathed in tears, near the fire of grief in the heart,

original: carati vimuktāhāraṃ vratam iva bhavato ripustrīṇām // / //
analyzed: carati vimukta āhāram vratam iva bhavataḥ ripu strīṇām
translated: are observing a vow without food, as if it were a vow.

original: saṃkalpe 'ṅkuritaṃ dvipatritam atha prasthānavelāgame mārge pallavitaṃ puraṃ praviśataḥ śākhāśatair udgatam /
analyzed: saṃkalpe ṅkuritam dvi patritam atha prasthāna velā game mārge pallavitam puram praviśataḥ śākhā śataiḥ udgatam
translated: When the desire sprouted, it had two leaves. At the time of departure, it had buds on the path. Entering the city, it rose with hundreds of branches.

original: prātarbhāvini darśane mukulitaṃ dṛṣṭe tu deva tvayi protphullaṃ phalitaṃ ca samprati manorājyadrumeṇādya me // / //
analyzed: prātar bhāvini darśane mukulitam dṛṣṭe tu deva tvayi protphullam phalitam ca samprati manaḥ rājya drumeṇa adya me  /
translated: When the meeting was to happen in the morning, it was closed. But seeing you, O Lord, today my wish-tree has blossomed and borne fruit.

original: bhūtivibhūṣitadehāḥ kāntārāgeṇa labdhamahimānaḥ /
analyzed: bhūti vibhūṣita dehāḥ kāntā rāgeṇa labdha mahimānaḥ
translated: Their bodies adorned with ash, having attained greatness through the love of Śiva,

original: trikaliṅganyastakarā bhavadarayas tvatsamā jātāḥ // / //
analyzed: trika liṅga nyasta karāḥ bhavat arayaḥ tvad samāḥ jātāḥ
translated: The three Kaliṅgas, their hands placed on your head, have become your enemies.

original: jāne vikramavardhana tvayi dhanaṃ viśrāṇayaty arthināṃ bhāvī śoṇa ivopalair upacito ratnair agādho 'mbudhiḥ /
analyzed: jāne vikramavardhana tvayi dhanam viśrāṇayati arthinām bhāvī śoṇaḥ iva upalaiḥ upacitaḥ ratnaiḥ agādhaḥ mbudhiḥ
translated: I know, O Vikramaditya, that in you the ocean of wealth will become fathomless with jewels, like the ocean filled with rocks, when it bestows wealth on supplicants.

original: tat paśyāmi ca rohaṇo maṇibharair ādhmāyamānodaraḥ pākotpīḍitadāḍimīphaladaśāṃ kaiścid dinair yāsyati // / //
analyzed: tat paśyāmi ca rohaṇaḥ maṇi bharaiḥ ādhmāyamāna udaraḥ pāka utpīḍita dāḍimī phala daśām kaiścid dinaiḥ yāsyati  /
translated: And I see that Rohana, its belly swollen with the weight of gems, will in a few days attain the state of a ripe pomegranate, bursting with ripened fruit.

original: ekas tridhā hṛdi sadā vasasi sma citraṃ yo vidviṣāṃ ca viduṣāṃ ca mṛgīdṛśāṃ ca /
analyzed: ekaḥ tridhā hṛdi sadā vasasi sma citram yaḥ vidviṣām ca viduṣām ca mṛgī dṛśām ca
translated: O you who always dwell in three ways in the heart, it is wonderful that you are in the hearts of enemies, scholars, and doe-eyed women.

original: tāpaṃ ca saṃmadarasaṃ ca ratiṃ ca tanvañ śauryoṣmaṇā ca vinayena ca līlayā ca // / //
analyzed: tāpam ca saṃmada rasam ca ratim ca tanvam śaurya ūṣmaṇā ca vinayena ca līlayā ca
translated: Causing heat, the taste of joy, and love, with the heat of valor, humility, and play.

original: deva tvām aham arthaye ciram asau varṣāgamo nirgatas tīrthaṃ tīrtham itas tato vicarituṃ ceto 'dhunā dhāvati /
analyzed: deva tvām aham arthaye ciram asau varṣa āgamaḥ nirgataḥ tīrtham tīrtham itas tatas vicaritum cetaḥ dhunā dhāvati
translated: O god, I request you, this long period of years has passed, and now my mind runs here and there to wander from one holy place to another.

original: tad viśrāmaya vīra vīryanibiḍajyābandhanāt kārmukaṃ mā bhūd vairivadhūvilocanajalair mārgakramo durgamaḥ // / //
analyzed: tat viśrāmaya vīra vīrya nibiḍa jyā bandhanāt kārmukam mā bhūt vairi vadhū vilocana jalaiḥ mārga kramaḥ durgamaḥ  /
translated: Therefore, O hero, rest your bow from the tight binding of the bowstring, lest the path become impassable with the tears from the eyes of the wives of your enemies.

original: dvirūpā samare rājann ekaivāsilatāvadhūḥ /
analyzed: dvirūpā samare rājan ekā eva asi latā vadhūḥ
translated: O king, in battle, the single sword-wife has two forms.

original: dārikārikarīndrāṇāṃ subhaṭānāṃ ca kuṭṭanī // / //🔽āmṛśya stanamaṇḍalaṃ pratimuhuḥ saṃcumbya gaṇḍasthalīṃ grīvāṃ pratyavalambya sambhramabalair āhanyamānaḥ karaiḥ /
analyzed: dārikā ari karīndrāṇām su bhaṭānām ca kuṭṭanī  āmṛśya stana maṇḍalam pratimuhur saṃcumbya gaṇḍa sthalīm grīvām pratyavalambya sambhrama balaiḥ āhanyamānaḥ karaiḥ
translated: The bawd of the best warriors, the leaders of the army of young men.🔽Having repeatedly touched the circle of her breasts, having kissed her cheek again and again, leaning on her neck, being struck by her hands with force out of excitement,

original: suptasyādrinadinikuñjagahane mattaḥ payodānilaiḥ karṇānte maśakaḥ kim apy arivadhūsārthasya te jalpati // / //
analyzed: suptasya adri nadi nikuñja gahane mattaḥ payoda anilaiḥ karṇa ante maśakaḥ kim api ari vadhū sārthasya te jalpati  /
translated: while you are sleeping in the dense forest of the mountain stream, intoxicated by the water and wind, a mosquito is whispering something in the ear of your enemy's wife.

original: lambamānanayanāmbubindavaḥ kandarāsu gahanāsu bhūbhṛtām /
analyzed: lambamāna nayana ambu bindavaḥ kandarāsu gahanāsu bhūbhṛtām
translated: The drops of tears hanging from her eyes, on the deep caves of the mountains,

original: ākapolatalalolakuntalāḥ saṃcaranti tava vairiyoṣitaḥ // / //
analyzed: ā kapola tala lola kuntalāḥ saṃcaranti tava vairi yoṣitaḥ
translated: with her hair loose up to her cheeks, your enemy's wife is wandering around.

original: mā te bhavatu śatrūṇāṃ yā śrutiḥ śrūyate kvipaḥ /
analyzed: mā te bhavatu śatrūṇām yā śrutiḥ śrūyate kvipaḥ
translated: Let not that word 'kvip' be heard by you, which is used in the case of enemies,

original: sārdhaṃ bandhubhir aṅgasya yā parasmaipade sici // / //
analyzed: sārdham bandhubhiḥ aṅgasya yā parasmaipade sici
translated: along with the relatives, in the optative mood of the root 'ang' (to be).

original: tat kalpadrumapuṣpasaṃstarirajas tat kāmadhenoḥ payas taṃ ca tryambakanetradagdhavapuṣaḥ puṣpāyudhasyānalam /
analyzed: tat kalpadruma puṣpa saṃstari rajaḥ tat kāmadhenoḥ payaḥ tam ca tryambaka netra dagdha vapuṣaḥ puṣpāyudhasya analam
translated: The pollen of the wish-fulfilling tree flowers, the milk of the wish-fulfilling cow, and the fire of the god of love, whose body was burned by the third eye of Shiva,

original: padmāyāḥ śvasitānilāni ca śaratkālasya tac ca sphuṭaṃ vyomādāya vinirmito 'si vidhinā kāmboja tubhyaṃ namaḥ // / //
analyzed: padmāyāḥ śvasita anilāni ca śarad kālasya tat ca sphuṭam vyom ādāya vinirmitaḥ si vidhinā kāmboja tubhyam namaḥ  /
translated: And the exhaled breath of Padmā, and that of the autumn season - you have been created by Brahmā, taking all this from the sky, O Kāmboja, salutations to you.

original: vasukalpasya
analyzed: vasukalpasya
translated: Of Vasukalpa

original: dviṣo bhavanti vīrendra mukhe na tava saṃmukhāḥ /
analyzed: dviṣaḥ bhavanti vīra indra mukhe na tava saṃmukhāḥ
translated: O lord of heroes, your enemies do not face you directly.

original: bhavadbhujabalaprauḍhi parityājitahetayaḥ // / //
analyzed: bhavat bhuja bala prauḍhi parityājita hetayaḥ
translated: Having abandoned their weapons, they are overwhelmed by the strength of your arms.

original: kṣiptaḥ kṣīragṛhe na dugdhajaladhiḥ koṣe na hemācalo dikpālā api pālipālanavidhav ānīya nāropitāḥ /
analyzed: kṣiptaḥ kṣīragṛhe na dugdha jaladhiḥ koṣe na hemācalaḥ dikpālāḥ api ānīya nā āropitāḥ
translated: The ocean of milk was not placed in the milk house, nor the mountain of gold in the treasury, nor were the guardians of the directions brought and installed for the protection of the boundaries.

original: no vā dikkarinaḥ kvaṇanmadhulihaḥ paryāyaparyāṇana krīḍāyāṃ viniyojitā vada kṛtaṃ kiṃ kiṃ tvayā digjaye // / //
analyzed: no vā dikkarinaḥ kvaṇat madhulihaḥ paryāya paryāṇana krīḍāyām viniyojitāḥ vada kṛtam kim kim tvayā digjaye  /
translated: Or the elephants of the directions, with buzzing bees, were not employed in the sport of circumambulation. Tell me, what have you done in the conquest of the directions?

original: dakṣasya🔽vāhavyūhakhurāgraṭaṅkavihatikṣuṇṇakṣamājanmabhir dhūlībhiḥ pihite vihāyasi bhavatprasthānakālotsave /
analyzed: dakṣasya  vāha vyūha khura agra ṭaṅka vihati kṣuṇṇa kṣamā janmabhiḥ dhūlībhiḥ pihite vihāyasi bhavat prasthāna kāla utsave
translated: Of Dakṣa🔽At the time of your departure, when the sky was covered with dust raised from the earth by the hooves and ploughs of the army of horses,

original: diṅmohākulasūrasūtavipathabhrāmyatturaṅgāvalī dīrghāyuḥkṛtavāsaraḥ pratidiśaṃ vyasto ravis tāmyati // / //
analyzed: diś moha ākula sūra sūta vipatha bhrāmyat turaṅga āvalī dīrgha āyuḥ kṛta vāsaraḥ pratidiśam vyastaḥ raviḥ tāmyati  /
translated: The line of horses of the sun, confused about the directions, wandering in the wrong path, the sun, having prolonged the day, is scattered in all directions and suffers.

original: dātaiṣa viśvaviditaḥ kim ayaṃ dadāti sarvāhitāni jagate nanu vārtam etat /
analyzed: dātā eṣa viśva viditaḥ kim ayam dadāti sarva ahitāni jagate nanu vārtam etat
translated: This is known to all: what does he give? He gives all that is harmful to the world, indeed, this is the news.

original: asyodayāt prabhṛti vāñchati dānapātraṃ cintāmaṇir yadi dadāti dadātu tāvat // / //
analyzed: asya udayāt prabhṛti vāñchati dāna pātram cintāmaṇiḥ yadi dadāti dadātu tāvat
translated: From his rise, the wish-fulfilling gem desires to be a recipient of charity. If it gives, let it give, as much as it likes.

original: aṅkokasya
analyzed: aṅkokasya
translated: Of Aṅkoka

original: pūrṇe 'gre kalaśo vilāsavanitāḥ smerānanāḥ kanyakā dānaklinnakapolapaddhatir ibho gauradyutir govṛṣaḥ /
analyzed: pūrṇe gre kalaśaḥ vilāsa vanitāḥ smera ānanāḥ kanyakāḥ dāna klinna kapola paddhatiḥ ibhaḥ gaura dyutiḥ go vṛṣaḥ
translated: In front is a full pot, young girls with smiling faces, an elephant with cheeks moist from giving, a bull with a white luster.

original: kṣīrakṣmāruhi vāyaso madhuravāg vāmā śiveti dhruvaṃ tvāṃ praty uccalatāṃ narendratilaka prādurbhavanty arthinām // / //
analyzed: kṣīra kṣmā ruhi vāyasaḥ madhura vāc vāmā śivā iti dhruvam tvām prati uccalatām narendra tilaka prādurbhavanti arthinām  /
translated: A crow on a tree of milk and resin, and a sweet-voiced female on Shiva - it is certain that for you, O crest-jewel of kings, when supplicants approach,

original: yato yato nṛpa nakhapṛṣṭhapāṭalaṃ vilocanaṃ calati tava prasīdataḥ /
analyzed: yatas yatas nṛpa nakha pṛṣṭha pāṭalam vilocanam calati tava prasīdataḥ
translated: From wherever your reddish-brown eye moves, O king, from the favor of your glance,

original: tatas tato nalinavanādhivāsinī tadīpsayā kila kamalānudhāvati // / //
analyzed: tatas tatas nalina vana adhivāsinī tad īpsayā kila kamalā anudhāvati  /
translated: From there, the lotus-eyed one, it is said, runs after the lotuses, desiring them.

original: parameśvarasya
analyzed: parameśvarasya
translated: Of the Supreme Lord

original: ruditaṃ vanecarair api vindhyādrinivāsibhis tavāriśiśau /
analyzed: ruditam vanecaraiḥ api vindhya adri nivāsibhiḥ tava ari śiśau
translated: The young ones of your enemies, even by the forest-dwellers living in the Vindhya mountains, are wept over.

original: vanamānuṣīṣu hastaṃ phalahastāsu prasārayati // / //
analyzed: vana mānuṣīṣu hastam phala hastāsu prasārayati  /
translated: It stretches out its hand to the forest women who have fruits in their hands.

original: ābaddhabhīmabhṛkuṭīsthapuṭaṃ lalāṭaṃ bibhrat parāṅmukharipor vidhutādharoṣṭhaḥ /
analyzed: ābaddha bhīma bhṛkuṭī stha puṭam lalāṭam bibhrat parāṅmukha ripoḥ vidhuta adhara uṣṭhaḥ
translated: Bearing a forehead with a frown knitted in a terrible manner, with the lower lip hanging down from the face turned away from the enemy,

original: ātmaiva saṅgaramukhe nijamaṇḍalāgra cchāyāchalād abhimukhas tava deva jātaḥ // / //
analyzed: ātmā eva saṅgara mukhe nija maṇḍala agra chāyā chalāt abhimukhaḥ tava deva jātaḥ  /
translated: That very self of yours, O Lord, has become facing you by the trick of the shadow of the tip of your own circle in the front of the battle.

original: nijagṛhamayūranāmabhir āhūtānāgateṣu vanaśikhiṣu /
analyzed: nija gṛha mayūra nāmabhiḥ āhūta anāgateṣu vana śikhiṣu
translated: When the forest peacocks, called by the names of the peacocks in your own house, did not come,

original: bālatanayena rudatā tvadarivadhūr roditā dīrgham // / //
analyzed: bāla tanayena rudatā tvad ari vadhūḥ roditā dīrgham
translated: The wife of your enemy wept long with her young son crying.

original: yogeśvarasya
analyzed: yogeśvarasya
translated: Of Yogesvara

original: ye tṛṣṇārtair adhikam aniśaṃ bhujyamānāḥ prasannā antarbhūtā jhaṭiti guṇino yatra pūrṇā bhavanti /
analyzed: ye tṛṣṇā ārtaiḥ adhikam aniśam bhujyamānāḥ prasannāḥ antarbhūtāḥ jhaṭiti guṇinaḥ yatra pūrṇāḥ bhavanti
translated: Those which are constantly enjoyed by the thirsty to excess, which are delighted and fully absorbed within, which become fully endowed with good qualities,

original: namrībhūtaiḥ phalam abhinavaṃ prāpyate yady avaśyaṃ tat kiṃ kūpāḥ sukṛtaghaṭitās tvādṛśā vā pumāṃsaḥ // / //
analyzed: namrībhūtaiḥ phalam abhinavam prāpyate yadi avaśyam tat kim kūpāḥ sukṛta ghaṭitāḥ tvādṛśāḥ vā pumāṃsaḥ  /
translated: If fresh fruit is obtained by those who have become humble, then are wells constructed with good deeds, or are men like you?

original: amaradattasya
analyzed: amaradattasya
translated: Of Amaradatta

original: bhrāntaṃ yena caturbhir eva caraṇaiḥ satyābhidhāne yuge tretāyāṃ tribhir aṅghribhiḥ katham api dvābhyāṃ tato dvāpare /
analyzed: bhrāntam yena caturbhiḥ eva caraṇaiḥ satya abhidhāne yuge tretāyām tribhiḥ aṅghribhiḥ katham api dvābhyām tatas dvāpare
translated: By whom the four ages were wandered with four feet only, in the age of truth, in the Treta age with three feet somehow, and then in the Dvapara with two,

original: na syāt tvaṃ yadi deva pudgalaguḍaḥ kāle kalaūtkale so 'yaṃ paṅgur avasthitaikacaraṇo dharmaḥ kathaṃ bhrāmyati // / //
analyzed: na syāt tvam yadi deva pudgala guḍaḥ kāle kalaśa utkale saḥ yam paṅguḥ avasthita eka caraṇaḥ dharmaḥ katham bhrāmyati  /
translated: If you were not the divine mace of the individual, this lame one, standing on one foot, how would the Dharma wander?

original: cittūkasya
analyzed: cittūkasya
translated: Of Cittūka

original: tvaṃ dharmabhūs tvam iha saṃgaramūrdhni bhīmaḥ kīrtyārjuno 'si nakulena tavopamāsti /
analyzed: tvam dharma bhūḥ tvam iha saṃgara mūrdhni bhīmaḥ kīrtyā arjunaḥ si nakulena tava upamā asti
translated: You are the Dharma ground, you are the terrible Arjuna in the forefront of battle, you are equal to Nakula.

original: tulyas tvayā yadi paraṃ sahadeva eva duḥśāsanas tava punar nanu ko 'pi śatruḥ // / //
analyzed: tulyaḥ tvayā yadi param sahadevaḥ eva duḥśāsanaḥ tava punar nanu kaḥ pi śatruḥ
translated: If Sahadeva is indeed equal to you, then Duhshāsana is certainly your enemy.

original: halāyudhasya
analyzed: halāyudhasya
translated: Of Halāyudha

original: kūrmaḥ pādo 'tra yaṣṭir bhujagapatir asau bhājanaṃ bhūtadhātrī tailotpūraḥ samudrāḥ kanakagirir ayaṃ vṛttavartiprarohaḥ /
analyzed: kūrmaḥ yaṣṭiḥ bhujaga patiḥ asau bhājanam bhūtadhātrī tailotpūraḥ samudrāḥ kanaka giriḥ ayam vṛtta varti prarohaḥ
